parts:
### Multiplicative Ergodic Theorem (Oseledets, 1965)

**Setting**

* A probability space \((X,\Sigma ,\mu )\).
* An invertible, measurable, **μ-preserving** map \(T:X\to X\).
* A measurable matrix cocycle  
  \[
    A:X\longrightarrow GL(d,\mathbb R),\qquad
    A^{(n)}(x)=A\bigl(T^{n-1}x\bigr)\dots A\bigl(Tx\bigr)A(x).
  \]
* **Log-integrability** (temperedness):
  \[
    \int_X \!\log^+\!\|A(x)\|\,d\mu(x)<\infty,\qquad
    \int_X \!\log^+\!\|A(x)^{-1}\|\,d\mu(x)<\infty .
  \]

**Theorem**

There exist integers  
\(1\le k\le d\), numbers  
\(\lambda_1>\lambda_2>\dots>\lambda_k\) (the **Lyapunov exponents**), and a measurable splitting

\[
\mathbb R^{d}=E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_k(x),\qquad x\in X,
\]

such that for μ-almost every \(x\):

* \(A^{(n)}(x)E_i(x)=E_i\!\bigl(T^{n}x\bigr)\) (covariance);
* for every non-zero \(v\in E_i(x)\),
  \[
    \lim_{n\to\pm\infty}\frac1n\log\bigl\|A^{(n)}(x)v\bigr\|=\lambda_i .
  \]

The numbers \(\dim E_i(x)\) are μ-a.s. constant and \(\sum_i\dim E_i=d\).

---

### When is ergodicity needed?

* **Existence of exponents and splitting:**  
  The above hypotheses are *sufficient*; **ergodicity is *not* required.**
* **Constancy of the exponents:**  
  If \(T\) is **ergodic**, then each \(\lambda_i\) and each \(\dim E_i\) is constant μ-a.s.  
  Without ergodicity they may depend on \(x\); the spectrum is piece-wise constant on the ergodic components of \(\mu\).

---

### Smooth dynamical systems (derivative cocycle)

* \(M\): compact \(C^{1}\) manifold,
* \(F:M\to M\) \(C^{1}\) (a diffeomorphism or just invertible a.e.),
* Cocycle \(A(x)=DF_x\).

The integrability conditions reduce to  
\(\int_M \log^+\!\|DF_x^{\pm1}\|\,d\mu(x)<\infty.\)  
Any invariant Borel probability measure \(\mu\) that satisfies this admits the Oseledets splitting in the tangent bundle \(T_xM\).

---

### Spatially varying Lyapunov *vectors*

Even for an ergodic measure the **directions** \(E_i(x)\) generally vary with \(x\); only in very special cases (e.g.\ linear toral automorphisms) are they constant. Spatial variation becomes pronounced in:

| Class of system | Reason Lyapunov subspaces vary spatially |
|-----------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **Non-ergodic maps / flows** | Different ergodic components carry different spectra and directions. |
| **Systems with continuous symmetries** (e.g.\ translation-invariant PDEs, coupled map lattices) | Neutral directions align with local symmetry generators; their orientation depends on the base point. |
| **Non-uniformly hyperbolic attractors** (Lorenz-63, Hénon, …) | Stable and unstable sub-bundles twist along the orbit; covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) change continuously but not uniformly. |
| **Spatiotemporal chaos** (Kuramoto–Sivashinsky, CGLE, CCA/Lenia) | State space is a function space; Oseledets subspaces themselves are functions of the spatial coordinate, so “vectors” vary both along the orbit and across the physical domain. |

A compact way to detect genuine spatial variability is to check whether the cocycle is **uniformly hyperbolic**; if not, Oseledets subspaces cannot be made constant by a smooth bundle trivialisation.

---

### Minimal checklist for an Oseledets splitting

1. **Measurable, μ-preserving transformation** \(T\) (invertible a.e.).
2. **Finite first moments** of \(\log^+\!\|A\|\) and \(\log^+\!\|A^{-1}\|\).
3. (If smooth system) \(M\) compact and \(F\) \(C^{1}\), or more generally: derivative satisfies the integrability bounds.

No further mixing, hyperbolicity, or ergodicity assumptions are mandatory. Erg­odicity simply upgrades “exponents exist μ-a.s.” to “the same exponents for almost every point”.

---

### Further reading

* Oseledets, **“A multiplicative ergodic theorem”**, Trans. Moscow Math. Soc. 19 (1968).  
* Ruelle, **“Characteristic exponents and invariant manifolds”**, Ann. Math. (1979).  
* Barreira & Pesin, *Lyapunov Exponents and Smooth Ergodic Theory* (2002) — Chapters 1–3.

parts:
**Short answer — Yes.**

---

### 1 Autonomous, stationary setting  
For a fixed, μ-preserving map or flow \(T^{t}\) and its cocycle \(A^{(t)}(x)=D T^{t}_{x}\):

* The Oseledets subspaces are measurable maps  
  \[
    E_i:\;X\;\longrightarrow\;{\rm Gr}(d,\dim E_i)\, ,
  \]
  so they depend on the **phase-space point** \(x\).

* Along an orbit \(x(t)=T^{t}x_0\) the directions evolve covariantly
  \[
     E_i\bigl(x(t)\bigr)=A^{(t)}(x_0)\,E_i(x_0).
  \]

If you watch a **fixed vector in ambient coordinates**—say, choose a unit vector
\(e_i(t)\in E_i\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\)—it generally **rotates with time**.  
Thus even in the purely autonomous, ergodic case each Lyapunov direction is a time-dependent object
\[
  e_i:\;\mathbb R\longrightarrow\mathbb R^{d},\quad
  t\mapsto e_i(t).
\]

---

### 2 Non-autonomous / random dynamical systems  
Put the time-dependence into the base:

* Base flow \(\theta^{t}:\Omega\!\to\!\Omega\) on a probability space \((\Omega,\mathcal F,{\mathbb P})\).
* Skew product \(\varPhi^{t}(\omega,x)\) on the state space \(X\).

Oseledets then yields subspaces  
\[
  E_i(\omega,x)\subset T_xX .
\]
When you follow a trajectory \((\omega(t),x(t))=(\theta^{t}\omega_0,\varPhi^{t}(\omega_0,x_0))\),
both arguments change, so \(E_i\) **explicitly depends on time even if \(x\) were frozen**.

---

### 3 Uniform vs. non-uniform hyperbolicity  
If the cocycle is **uniformly hyperbolic** (Anosov), there exists a continuous trivialisation in which the stable/unstable bundles look constant; otherwise the directions *must* vary.  Most real-world chaotic systems are only *non-uniformly* hyperbolic, so their covariant Lyapunov vectors twist continuously in time.

---

### 4 Finite-time viewpoints  
Finite-time Lyapunov vectors (FTLVs) and finite-time Oseledets splittings are always functions of the chosen horizon \(T\); taking the limit \(T\to\infty\) gives the asymptotic (time-independent in distribution) exponents, but the associated **vector directions never freeze** unless the cocycle can be simultaneously diagonalised.

---

### 5 Summary of “when” they vary

| Scenario | Do directions depend on \(t\)? | Mechanism |
|----------|--------------------------------|-----------|
| Autonomous map/flow, ergodic | **Yes** | They are functions of the current state \(x(t)\). |
| Non-ergodic invariant measure | **Yes** | State jumps between ergodic components with distinct splittings. |
| Time-periodic, quasi-periodic, stochastic forcing | **Yes** | Extra base coordinate \(\omega(t)\) enters \(E_i(\omega,x)\). |
| Uniformly hyperbolic linear system diagonal in fixed basis | **No** | All \(E_i\) are constant subspaces; this is exceptional. |

So, **“most generally” the Lyapunov directions are time-dependent functions—of time through the evolving state, and (for driven systems) through the driving process itself.**

No—only those vectors having a non-zero component in the fastest subspace end up growing with the largest exponent.  
The multiplicative–ergodic decomposition makes this precise.

---

### Decompose any vector once the Oseledets splitting exists
For μ-a.e. point \(x\) we have

\[
\mathbb R^{d}=E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_k(x),\qquad
\lambda_1>\lambda_2>\dots>\lambda_k .
\]

Given a non-zero \(v\in\mathbb R^{d}\) write the unique decomposition

\[
v=\sum_{i=1}^{k}v_i,\qquad v_i\in E_i(x).
\]

---

### Growth rate of that vector

\[
A^{(n)}(x)v=\sum_{i=1}^{k}A^{(n)}(x)v_i
           =\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathrm{e}^{n\lambda_i+o(n)}\,\hat v_i(n),
\]
with \(\hat v_i(n)\) bounded away from zero and infinity as \(n\to\infty\).

Hence

\[
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}(x)v\|
      =\max\{\lambda_i:\,v_i\neq 0\}.
\]

* **Generic vector** has \(v_1\neq 0\) ⇒ growth rate \(=\lambda_1\).
* **Exact restriction** If \(v\) lies entirely in \(E_j(x)\) (all higher-index components zero) then the rate is \(\lambda_j\).

Because \(E_j(x)\) has codimension \(\sum_{i<j}\dim E_i\), the probability that a randomly chosen direction lands *exactly* inside a lower-rank subspace is zero unless you pick it intentionally.

---

### Geometric intuition

* The flow stretches most strongly along \(E_1(x)\).  
  Any little component in that direction is amplified by \(\mathrm{e}^{n\lambda_1}\) and eventually dominates every weaker component.
* Vectors that remain governed by a smaller exponent are the ones **initially embedded in the corresponding invariant subspace**; the dynamics never mix those subspaces with faster ones, so no leakage can create a component along \(E_1\).

---

### Practical corollaries

1. **Covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs).**  
   Each \(E_i(x)\) is spanned by the \(i\)-th CLV; they are the only directions whose finite-time growth rates converge to \(\lambda_i\).

2. **Finite-time Lyapunov exponents computed from arbitrary initial vectors** converge to \(\lambda_1\) unless you re-orthonormalise (which is why the standard algorithm repeatedly performs QR or Gram–Schmidt).

3. **Systems admitting spatially varying Lyapunov directions** (your original interest) still obey the same rule point-wise: almost every perturbation field ultimately aligns with the local fastest CLV field.

So “all vectors go to the largest exponent’’ is true **except** for the exceptional set that lies wholly inside a slower Oseledets subspace—and those subspaces exist precisely because the cocycle keeps them separate.

parts:
Exactly.  Formalising it:

*Let \(v\neq0\) and write it in the Oseledets decomposition at the base point \(x\):*

\[
v=\sum_{i=1}^k v_i ,\qquad v_i\in E_i(x).
\]

Define  

\[
j=\min\{\,i\;|\;v_i\neq0\;\}.
\]

Because the exponents are ordered \(\lambda_1>\lambda_2>\dots>\lambda_k\),

\[
\|A^{(n)}(x)\,v\|
   =\bigl\|e^{n\lambda_j+o(n)}\,\hat v_j(n)+
         \sum_{i>j}e^{n\lambda_i+o(n)}\,\hat v_i(n)\bigr\|
   =e^{n\lambda_j+o(n)}\|\hat v_j(n)+\text{smaller terms}\|.
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\;
\displaystyle
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}(x)v\|=\lambda_j
\;} .
\]

So:

* If \(v\) lies **entirely in** \(E_j(x)\), then \(j\) is that index and the rate is exactly \(\lambda_j\).
* If \(v\) lives in the **direct sum** \(E_j(x)\oplus E_{j+1}(x)\oplus\dots\), the growth rate is still \(\lambda_j\) provided the \(E_j\)-component is non-zero; otherwise it drops to the next available exponent.

Equivalently,

\[
\chi(v):=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}v\|
      =\max\{\lambda_i\;|\;v_i\neq0\}.
\]

Thus a vector “inherits’’ the *largest* Lyapunov exponent among the subspaces it actually occupies.

thoughts.content: To determine if a vector \( v \) lies in a subspace based on the Oseledets splitting, we can't rely on simple projections due to the non-orthogonality of the subspaces. Instead, one approach is to use the basis vectors of those subspaces. You can decompose \( v \) by solving a linear system with the chosen basis. Another option is applying techniques like Gram-Schmidt or QR factorization, though these methods rely on orthogonalization, which isn’t necessary for the subspaces here.

To check if a vector lies in the span of slower time scales (subspaces), we need to project it onto the simultaneous basis of faster subspaces. Since the CLVs are not orthogonal, we can use the dual basis (backward modes) to compute these projections. The key is calculating the coefficients by solving a linear system or checking linear dependence. Alternatively, using QR decomposition with the adjoint vectors or CLV matrix would reveal contributions. Conceptually, a vector lies in the slower subspace if the projections onto faster subspaces are zero.

parts:
Because the Oseledets sub-spaces are only **transverse**, not orthogonal, you cannot test membership with a Euclidean projection.  What you need is a **dual (left) basis** that is bi-orthogonal to the covariant (right) Lyapunov basis.

---

### 1 Build a bi-orthogonal pair

At the base point \(x\) let  

\[
V(x)=\bigl[v_{1}(x)\;\dots\;v_{d}(x)\bigr]
\]

be the matrix whose columns are the covariant Lyapunov vectors, ordered so that  
\(\operatorname{span}\{v_{i},\dots ,v_{d}\}=E_{i}(x)\).

Because the splitting is direct, \(V(x)\in GL(d,\mathbb R)\) and therefore has an inverse.  Define its inverse transpose

\[
W(x):=V(x)^{-\top}
      =\bigl[w_{1}(x)\;\dots\;w_{d}(x)\bigr],
\qquad
W(x)^{\!\top}V(x)=I .
\]

The columns \(w_{i}(x)\) are the **dual (left) Lyapunov vectors**.  They satisfy the bi-orthogonality relation  

\[
w_{i}(x)^{\!\top} v_{j}(x)=\delta_{ij}.
\]

---

### 2 Coordinates of an arbitrary tangent vector

For any \(u\in T_{x}M\),

\[
u = V(x)\,c
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
c = W(x)^{\!\top}u,
\qquad
c_i = w_{i}(x)^{\!\top}u .
\]

The coefficient \(c_i\) is the *unique* scalar multiplying \(v_i\) in the Oseledets decomposition.

---

### 3 Membership test for the “slower” bundle

Let  

\[
F_{j}(x)=E_{j}(x)\oplus E_{j+1}(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_{k}(x)
        =\operatorname{span}\{v_{j},\dots ,v_{d}\}.
\]

A vector \(u\) lies in \(F_{j}(x)\) **iff**

\[
c_1=c_2=\dots =c_{\,j-1}=0
\quad\;\Longleftrightarrow\;\quad
w_{i}(x)^{\!\top}u = 0\quad (1\le i<j).
\]

Thus the dual vectors act as *oblique projectors* onto the fast directions; vanishing of all projections up to \(j-1\) means “no component in the faster sub-spaces.”

---

### 4 Numerical implementation (Ginelli–Wolf algorithm)

1. Integrate forward to obtain the **covariant** matrix \(V\).  
2. Integrate the adjoint (or simply invert \(V\)) to get **left** vectors \(W\).  
3. Compute the coefficients \(c = W^{\!\top}u\).  
4. Declare \(u\in F_{j}\) if \(\max_{i<j}|c_i|\) is below tolerance.

This avoids the ill-conditioning that would occur if you tried to use Euclidean orthogonal projections on a highly skew basis.

---

### 5 Conceptual takeaway

*Orthogonality is irrelevant; linear independence is enough.*  
The Oseledets splitting provides a basis \(V\).  Its algebraic inverse (or, equivalently, the adjoint evolution) furnishes the dual basis \(W\).  A vector is contained in the “smaller” (slower) bundle precisely when **all dual projections onto the faster bundles vanish.**

parts:
### Multiplicative-ergodic theorem **without** the ergodicity assumption  

Let \((X,\Sigma ,\mu )\) be **µ-invariant but not necessarily ergodic**,  
\(T:X\to X\) invertible a.e., and \(A:X\to GL(d,\mathbb R)\) a measurable cocycle satisfying the usual log–integrability.  
Oseledets still gives, for μ-a.e. \(x\),

\[
\mathbb R^{d}=E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_{k(x)}(x),\qquad
\lambda_1(x)>\lambda_2(x)>\dots>\lambda_{k(x)}(x).
\]

The new feature is that the **Lyapunov exponents and the multiplicities now depend on the base point**:

\[
\lambda_i(Tx)=\lambda_i(x),\qquad
\dim E_i(Tx)=\dim E_i(x)\quad\text{a.e.}
\]

They are therefore **constant on every ergodic component** of \(\mu\) but can jump from one component to another.

---

### Stretch (growth) rate of an arbitrary vector  

Fix \(x\) in the full-measure Oseledets set and decompose \(v\in\mathbb R^{d}\):

\[
v=\sum_{i=1}^{k(x)} v_i,\qquad v_i\in E_i(x).
\]

Let  

\[
j(x,v)=\min\{\,i : v_i\neq0\}.
\]

Then exactly as in the ergodic case

\[
\boxed{\;
\chi(x,v):=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\bigl\|A^{(n)}(x)v\bigr\|
        =\lambda_{\,j(x,v)}(x)
\;}.
\]

So the stretching rate (finite-time growth exponent) is the **largest Lyapunov exponent, evaluated at \(x\), among the sub-spaces that the vector actually occupies**.  
Because the spectrum itself depends on \(x\), two nearby points can exhibit different asymptotic rates even if the vectors are parallel.

---

### How the rates vary in state space

* **Ergodic decomposition:**  
  Write \(\mu=\int_{\alpha\in\mathcal A}\mu_\alpha\,d\nu(\alpha)\) with each  
  \(\mu_\alpha\) ergodic.  
  For \(\mu_\alpha\)-a.e. \(x\) the list \(\{\lambda_i(x)\}\) equals the fixed numbers \(\{\lambda_i^{(\alpha)}\}\).  
  Hence the field \(x\mapsto\lambda_i(x)\) is *piece-wise constant*, jumping only when you cross the (µ-negligible) boundaries between ergodic components.

* **Non-ergodic physical situation:**  
  Take, for instance, a map whose phase space splits into two disjoint chaotic attractors \(A_+\) and \(A_-\) with different expansion rates.  
  Any orbit that starts in \(A_+\) keeps the stretch rates attached to \(A_+\);  
  another orbit in \(A_-\) keeps the other set of rates.  
  A global invariant measure that gives positive weight to both attractors is non-ergodic, and the spectrum is \(x\)-dependent exactly in the sense above.

* **Random or non-autonomous forcing:**  
  If \(T\) itself carries an explicit \(\omega\)-dependence, the exponents become functions of the driving path as well: \(\lambda_i(\omega,x)\).  
  Even after fixing \(x\), the values can fluctuate when \(\omega\) changes.

---

### Global summaries when you *need* a single number

Because the field \(x\mapsto\lambda_i(x)\) is measurable, two useful extremal quantities are  

\[
\lambda_i^{\min}:=\operatorname*{ess\,inf}_{x}\lambda_i(x),
\qquad
\lambda_i^{\max}:=\operatorname*{ess\,sup}_{x}\lambda_i(x).
\]

They bound every possible finite-time stretch rate:

\[
\lambda_i^{\min}\;\le\;
\chi(x,v)
\;\le\;\lambda_1^{\max}.
\]

But unless \(\mu\) is ergodic there is **no single “system-wide” Lyapunov exponent**; instead there is a *Lyapunov-exponent field* \(\lambda_i(x)\) whose value must be evaluated at the specific initial condition (or on the ergodic component you are interested in).

---

### Take-home message  

*The multiplicative-ergodic theorem is pointwise; without ergodicity every point (more precisely, every ergodic component) furnishes its own Lyapunov spectrum.  A perturbation vector stretches at the largest exponent available **at that point**, restricted to the sub-spaces it actually touches.*

thoughts.summary: Addressing lim sup in Lyapunov exponent literature
thoughts.content: The user is concerned about the necessity of lim sup in defining Lyapunov exponents and growth rates. The literature often uses lim sup because, in setting like the multiplicative ergodic theorem, lim sup always exists, unlike the limit. In systems where integrability conditions are satisfied, Oseledets' theorem assures the existence of limits for vectors within the subspace, but not for arbitrary vectors. A limit might not exist due to oscillations, whereas lim sup will always match the maximum exponent in those cases.

thoughts.summary: Explaining why lim sup is used in Lyapunov exponents
thoughts.content: In the context of Lyapunov exponents, a limit exists for almost every vector, especially when decomposed into the subspaces of Oseledets. However, when exponents are equal, convergence may fail, but lim sup can still be used to guarantee an upper bound. Literature often relies on lim sup to define the exponent universally, even in cases where a limit might not exist, which accounts for systems not satisfying ergodic or integrability conditions. Under Oseledets’ theory, the limit is always achievable for relevant subspaces.

parts:
Strictly speaking **lim sup is only a safety-net**.  
Under the hypotheses of the multiplicative-ergodic theorem the *plain limit* exists for μ-a.e. base point and for every vector lying in the Oseledets splitting, so one can write

\[
\chi(x,v)\;=\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}(x)v\|
      \quad\text{a.s.}
\]

The two places where authors still prefer  
\(\displaystyle \limsup_{n\to\infty}\tfrac1n\log\|\cdot\|\) are:

| Why use lim sup? | What fails if you drop to “lim”? |
|------------------|----------------------------------|
| **No integrability** (or badly behaved cocycle) | Oseledets cannot be applied; the limit need not exist, but the lim sup is finite and always defined. |
| **Generic upper-exponent definitions** (before invoking MET) | One wants a quantity that exists unconditionally, then later proves that the lim sup is in fact a limit almost everywhere once the MET conditions are imposed. |

---

### Where the *limit* does exist

* **For the norms of exterior powers**  
  \(\displaystyle \frac1n\log\|\wedge^k A^{(n)}(x)\|\) :  
  Kingman’s sub-additive ergodic theorem gives convergence without any splitting.

* **For an arbitrary vector when Oseledets splitting exists**  
  Decompose \(v=\sum_i v_i\) with \(v_i\in E_i(x)\).  
  Only the fastest non-zero component matters, and its growth is \(e^{n\lambda_j+o(n)}\); dividing the \(o(n)\) term by \(n\) forces it to zero, so the limit equals \(\lambda_j(x)\).

* **Even with multiple equal exponents**  
  If \(\lambda_j=\lambda_{j+1}\) the two components may interfere and make the *prefactor* oscillate, but  
  \[
  \frac1n\log\bigl(e^{n\lambda_j}\,(\text{bounded factor})\bigr)
  =\lambda_j+\tfrac1n\log(\text{bounded factor})
  \to\lambda_j .
  \]

---

### When the limit can genuinely fail

Remove the MET hypotheses—for example, drop **log-integrability**:

```text
Let T be an irrational rotation on the circle.
Set A(x)=diag(e^{\;f(x)},e^{-f(x)}) with   f(x)= \begin{cases}
             n & \text{if } x\in[0,2^{-n})\\
            -n & \text{if } x\in[2^{-n},2^{-(n-1)})
           \end{cases}
```

The partial products \(A^{(n)}(x)\) make

### Bottom line

* **If you have the Oseledets theorem in force** (measurable, μ-preserving map + log-integrable cocycle), you may safely replace every “lim sup” with a true limit—µ-almost everywhere.

No—ergodicity is **not** needed for the *limit* itself to exist.  
It is needed only if you want the limit to be the **same number everywhere**.

---

### What the multiplicative-ergodic theorem (MET) actually says

Let  

* \((X,\Sigma ,\mu ,T)\) be **µ-preserving**, but not necessarily ergodic;
* \(A:X\!\to\!GL(d,\mathbb R)\) a measurable cocycle with  
  \(\displaystyle\int\!\log^+\!\|A^{\pm1}\|\;d\mu<\infty\).

Then for μ-almost every \(x\)

\[
\lambda_1(x)>\dots>\lambda_{k(x)}(x),\qquad
\mathbb R^{d}=E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_{k(x)}(x)
\]

and for **every** non-zero \(v_i\in E_i(x)\)

\[
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\bigl\|A^{(n)}(x)v_i\bigr\|=\lambda_i(x).
\]

These statements do **not** assume ergodicity.

---

### Consequences for an arbitrary vector \(v\)

Decompose \(v=\sum_i v_i\) with \(v_i\in E_i(x)\) and let  
\(j=\min\{i\mid v_i\neq0\}\).  Then

\[
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}(x)v\|=\lambda_j(x),
\]

again with no ergodicity assumption.  The proof is identical to the ergodic case: the fastest non-zero component dominates and the \(o(n)\) term vanishes when divided by \(n\).

---

### Where ergodicity *is* used

* **Constancy of the spectrum.**  
  If \(T\) is ergodic, each \(\lambda_i(x)\) and \(\dim E_i(x)\) is a genuine constant (µ-a.e.).  
  Without ergodicity they are merely *invariant functions*: constant on every ergodic component, possibly different from one component to another.

* **A single “Lyapunov exponent of the system”.**  
  To quote a number that does **not** depend on the initial condition you must first restrict to an ergodic component or average over one.

Nothing else in the MET requires ergodicity.

---

### Why authors still write “lim sup”

When the integrability hypothesis is not yet verified—or when one wants a definition that survives outside the MET framework—\(\limsup\limits_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}v\|\) is always defined.  
Once the MET applies (ergodic or not) that lim sup is automatically an ordinary limit, but many papers keep the cautious notation for historical or stylistic reasons.

---

**Bottom line:**  
*Pointwise limits for Lyapunov growth rates exist under the log-integrability assumption alone; ergodicity is only a device for making those limits independent of \(x\).*

### Notation

For one fixed time horizon \(t>0\) denote the tangent map (Jacobian of the flow or map)

\[
A(t,x)=D\Phi^{t}_{x}\;:\;\mathbb R^{d}\longrightarrow\mathbb R^{d}.
\]

Its finite–time **singular–value decomposition**

\[
A \;=\;U\;\Sigma\;V^{\top},\qquad
\Sigma=\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1\ge\dots\ge\sigma_d),
\]

gives two *orthonormal* bases

* right singular vectors \(V=[v^{\,(r)}_{1},\dots,v^{\,(r)}_{d}]\);
* left  singular vectors \(U=[v^{\,(l)}_{1},\dots,v^{\,(l)}_{d}]\);

such that \(A\,v^{\,(r)}_{i}=\sigma_i v^{\,(l)}_{i}\).

These **finite-time Lyapunov (Gram–Schmidt) vectors** are *not* the
**covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs)** of the Oseledets splitting.

---

## How a covariant vector is built from the two orthogonal flags

### 1 Forward and backward flags

Write the *flags* (nested subspaces)

\[
F_i^{\,+}(t,x)=\operatorname{span}\{v^{\,(r)}_{1},\dots ,v^{\,(r)}_{i}\},
\qquad
F_i^{\,-}(t,x)=\operatorname{span}\{v^{\,(l)}_{i},\dots ,v^{\,(l)}_{d}\}.
\]

They satisfy the covariance properties

\[
A\,F_i^{\,+}(t,x)=F_i^{\,+}\bigl(t,\Phi^{t}x\bigr),
\qquad
A^{-1}\,F_i^{\,-}(t,x)=F_i^{\,-}\bigl(t,\Phi^{-t}x\bigr).
\]

When the time window is let grow, the limits of these two sequences of
flags converge (almost surely) to the **forward** and **backward Lyapunov
flags** of the multiplicative–ergodic theorem.

### 2 Intersection formula (Ginelli et al. 2007)

For every index \(i\)

\[
\boxed{\;
E_i(x)\;=\;
F_i^{\,+}(t\!\to\!\infty,x)
\;\cap\;
F_i^{\,-}(t\!\to\!\infty,x)
\;},
\tag{1}
\]

i.e.

\[
E_i(x)
  =\operatorname*{span}\bigl\{v_1^{\,(r)},\dots ,v_i^{\,(r)}\bigr\}
    \;\cap\;
   \operatorname*{span}\bigl\{v_i^{\,(l)},\dots ,v_d^{\,(l)}\bigr\}.
\]

Geometrically the \(i\)-th **covariant Lyapunov vector**
\(v_i(x)\) is the unique (up to scale) vector that belongs
simultaneously to the first \(i\) *forward* directions and to the last
\(d-i+1\) *backward* directions.

Equation (1) is the only exact, time-asymptotic relation that ties CLVs
to the orthonormal singular bases.  There is **no single finite-time
SVD** that already contains the CLVs by algebraic manipulation of \(U\)
and \(V\) alone; one always needs *both* time directions (or, in
practice, two passes through the trajectory).

---

## Practical algebraic formula (Kuptsov & Parlitz 2012)

Let \(Q^{+}(x)\) be the \(d\times d\) matrix whose columns are the
orthonormal forward Gram–Schmidt vectors obtained by any standard QR
algorithm run **forward** in time; let \(Q^{-}(x)\) be the analogous
matrix from an adjoint (or inverse) QR pass run **backward** in time.
Define the \(d\times d\) *projection matrix*

\[
P(x)=Q^{-}(x)^{\!\top} Q^{+}(x).
\]

Compute its LU (or RQ) factorisation

\[
P = L\,U,
\qquad
U\text{ upper triangular}.
\]

Then the matrix of CLVs is

\[
\Gamma(x)=Q^{+}(x)\;U^{-1}.
\]

Its \(i\)-th column \(\gamma_i(x)\) equals \(v_i(x)\) (up to whichever
normalisation you want).  Every \(\gamma_i\) is, by construction,
covariant and reproduces the Oseledets splitting, while the columns of
\(Q^{\pm}\) remain orthonormal.

---

## Summary

* **Right/left singular vectors** (or QR‐Gram–Schmidt bases) give two
  *orthogonal* flags \(F_i^{\,+}\) and \(F_i^{\,-}\).
* **Covariant Lyapunov vector \(v_i\)** is the unique direction in the
  intersection \(F_i^{\,+}\cap F_i^{\,-}\).
* Expressing \(v_i\) numerically requires **both** flags; one SVD (or one
  forward integration) is insufficient.
* An explicit matrix formula is
  \(\Gamma=Q^{+}\,U^{-1}\) after an LU/RQ decomposition of
  \(Q^{-\,\top}Q^{+}\). This is what most “Ginelli-Wolf” type codes
  implement in practice.

U and V are orthonormal vectors that describe the directions of maximum stretching and compression in some finite-time horizon. These can be linked to Lyapunov vectors because, over time, they align with unstable or stable directions that maximize energy growth. We can approximate their alignment with forward and backward Lyapunov bases using theory from Oseledets’ splitting and Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization methods.

Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization provides an intuitive connection between the singular vectors from SVD and Lyapunov vectors. Forward-time application yields backward Lyapunov vectors, and the reverse gives the forward direction. For large time horizons, the right singular vectors (V) approximate forward Lyapunov vectors, and the left singular vectors (U) estimate the backward directions. They’re considered integrated proxies for Lyapunov vectors but aren’t covariant. ### 1 What \(V\) and \(U\) really are

For a fixed time horizon \(T>0\) let the tangent map be  
\(A_T(x)=D\Phi^{T}_{x}\).  
Its singular–value decomposition

\[
A_T = U_T\,\Sigma_T\,V_T^{\!\top},\qquad
\Sigma_T=\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1\!\ge\!\dots\!\ge\!\sigma_d)
\]

gives two orthonormal frames

* **right** singular vectors \(V_T(x)=\bigl[v^{(r)}_{1},\dots,v^{(r)}_{d}\bigr]\);
* **left**  singular vectors \(U_T(x)=\bigl[v^{(l)}_{1},\dots,v^{(l)}_{d}\bigr]\).

They diagonalise the **finite-time Cauchy–Green strain tensors**

\[
C_T(x)=A_T^{\!\top}A_T=V_T\,\Sigma_T^{2}\,V_T^{\!\top},\quad
\tilde C_T(\Phi^{T}x)=A_TA_T^{\!\top}=U_T\,\Sigma_T^{2}\,U_T^{\!\top}.
\]

Hence  

* \(v^{(r)}_{i}\) is the direction that maximises stretching **over the *whole* interval \([0,T]\)** with growth factor \(\sigma_i\);  
* \(v^{(l)}_{i}\) is the corresponding image direction at time \(T\).

---

### 2 Relation to Lyapunov objects

| Object | Definition | Invariant? | Orthogonal? | Limit as \(T\to\infty\) |
|--------|------------|------------|-------------|-------------------------|
| **Right/left singular vectors** \(V_T,U_T\) | Eigen‐bases of \(C_T,\tilde C_T\) | No | Yes | Converge to *flags* \(F_i^{+},F_i^{-}\) (see below) |
| **Gram–Schmidt (QR) vectors** | Orthonormalised columns during forward/backward integration | No | Yes | Same limits as above |
| **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** \(v_i\) | Intersections \(E_i=F_i^{+}\cap F_i^{-}\) | **Yes** | No | Independent of orthonormalisation |

---

#### Forward and backward flags  
Take any orthonormal QR procedure:

* run **forward**: obtain \(q^{+}_1,\dots ,q^{+}_d\) ⇒ nested subspaces  
  \(F_i^{+}(x)=\operatorname{span}\{q^{+}_1,\dots ,q^{+}_i\}\);
* run **backward** (or on the adjoint): obtain \(q^{-}_d,\dots ,q^{-}_1\) ⇒  
  \(F_i^{-}(x)=\operatorname{span}\{q^{-}_i,\dots ,q^{-}_d\}\).

Both constructions, **and likewise \(V_T,U_T\)**, converge almost surely to these two measurable flags as \(T\to\infty\).

#### Covariant (Oseledets) subspaces  
The \(i\)-th covariant subspace is

\[
E_i(x)=F_i^{+}(x)\;\cap\;F_i^{-}(x),
\tag{∗}
\]

and the covariant Lyapunov vector \(v_i(x)\) is the unique (up to scale) vector in that one-dimensional intersection.  Formula (∗) is the rigorous bridge between the orthonormal SVD frames and the non-orthogonal, invariant CLVs.

---

### 3 So are \(U_T,V_T\) “integrated” Lyapunov (co)vectors?

* **Yes, in a finite-time sense:**  
  They give the directions that accumulate the *largest* stretch or compression **over the chosen window**.  They can be viewed as “time-integrated extremal directions.”
* **No, for invariance:**  
  They are **not covariant**: applying the flow for another \(\tau\) does *not* send \(v^{(r)}_{i}(x)\) to \(v^{(r)}_{i}(\Phi^{\tau}x)\).  Only the vectors obtained via the double-limit construction (intersection of the two flags) enjoy that property.
* **Connection:**  
  When \(T\) is large, the leading columns of \(V_T,U_T\) lie exponentially close to the corresponding flags \(F_i^{+},F_i^{-}\); taking both and intersecting them removes the orthogonality constraint and produces the genuine covariant vector.

In short, **\(V_T\) and \(U_T\) are finite-time orthonormal “integrated-stretch” bases; the covariant Lyapunov vectors are their asymptotic, invariant cores obtained by combining forward and backward information.**

---

### Definitions side-by-side  

\[
\begin{aligned}
E_i(x)      &=\{v\neq0 : \chi(x,v)=\lambda_i\},\\
F_i(x)      &=\bigoplus_{j\ge i}E_j(x)
            =\{v\neq0 : \chi(x,v)\le\lambda_i\}.
\end{aligned}
\]

* \(E_i\) is the *exact* λ-\(i\) eigenspace.  
* \(F_i\) is the *flag* that contains **all** directions whose growth rate is *no faster* than λ-\(i\).

---

### What happens to a vector in \(F_i\)?

Write \(v=\sum_{j\ge i}v_j\) with \(v_j\in E_j\) and let  
\(r=\min\{j\ge i: v_j\neq0\}\).  
Then

\[
\chi(x,v)=\lambda_{\,r}\;\le\;\lambda_i,
\]

with strict inequality whenever \(v_i=0\).

So:

* If \(v_i\neq0\) ⇒ \(\chi(x,v)=\lambda_i\).
* If \(v_i=0\)  ⇒ \(\chi(x,v)=\lambda_{\,r}<\lambda_i\).

The first case is “generic’’ (missing a given subspace is measure-zero), but nothing in the definition of \(F_i\) **forces** that component to be present.  Hence \(F_i\) contains vectors whose Lyapunov exponent is λ-\(i\) **and** vectors with strictly smaller exponents.

---

### Simple 2-D example  

Let exponents be λ₁=2, λ₂=−1 with

\[
E_1=\operatorname{span}(e_x),\qquad
E_2=\operatorname{span}(e_y).
\]

Then \(F_1=\mathbb R^{2}\).

* Vector \((1,0)\in F_1\) grows like \(e^{2t}\).  
* Vector \((0,1)\in F_1\) decays like \(e^{-t}\).  
* Vector \((\varepsilon,1)\in F_1\) initially grows like \(e^{-t}\) but
  eventually switches to \(e^{2t}\) once the small \(e^{2t}\varepsilon\) piece dominates.

All three vectors are in \(F_1\), yet they realise different asymptotic rates.

---

### Terminology recap  

* **\(E_i\)** – directions with exponent **exactly** λ-\(i\).  
* **\(F_i\)** – directions with exponent **at most** λ-\(i\) (a filtration).

You can therefore assert  
\[
\chi(x,v)\le\lambda_i\quad\text{for all }v\in F_i(x),
\]  
but you cannot replace “≤” by “=” without additionally requiring
\(v\notin F_{i+1}(x)\), i.e. \(v_i\neq0\).

That “ \(\oplus\) ” is the **direct-sum symbol** from linear-algebra notation.

### Ordinary sum vs. direct sum of sub-spaces
For two sub-spaces \(U,V\subset\mathbb R^{d}\):

* **Sum**  
  \(U+V=\{u+v:\;u\in U,\;v\in V\}\).  
  The decomposition \(w=u+v\) need *not* be unique; \(U\cap V\) can be non-zero.

* **Direct sum**  
  \(U\;\oplus\;V:=\{u+v\!:\;u\in U,\;v\in V\;\text{and }U\cap V=\{0\}\}\).  
  The extra condition \(U\cap V=\{0\}\) guarantees **uniqueness**: every vector
  in \(U\oplus V\) has exactly one pair \((u,v)\).

For several sub-spaces \(E_1,\dots ,E_k\) the statement

\[
\mathbb R^{d}=E_1\;\oplus\;E_2\;\oplus\;\dots\;\oplus\;E_k
\]

means

1. **Spanning:** every vector \(w\in\mathbb R^{d}\) can be written as  
   \(w=\sum_{i=1}^{k} v_i\) with \(v_i\in E_i\);
2. **Pairwise trivial intersections:** \(E_i\cap E_j=\{0\}\) for \(i\neq j\), so the representation is unique.

### In the Oseledets context
The multiplicative-ergodic theorem provides a direct-sum decomposition of the tangent space (or \(\mathbb R^{d}\) in a linear cocycle) into the Lyapunov sub-spaces \(E_i(x)\):

\[
T_xM \;=\; E_1(x)\;\oplus\;E_2(x)\;\oplus\;\dots\;\oplus\;E_k(x).
\]

* Each \(E_i(x)\) collects the directions with exponent \(\lambda_i\).
* Because the sum is **direct**, no non-zero vector belongs simultaneously to two different \(E_i(x)\).  
  That’s why, when you decompose \(v=\sum_i v_i\), you can identify the “fastest non-zero component’’ unambiguously.

So the “plus’’ sign you noticed is not ordinary addition; it’s the **direct-sum operator**, signalling a *unique* splitting of the space into those invariant sub-spaces.

### Why the **right singular vectors** are *not* the covariant Lyapunov directions

#### 1 What makes a covariant Lyapunov vector special?
For a linear update \(x_{n+1}=A\,x_n\) the \(i\)-th **covariant Lyapunov vector** (CLV) \(v_i\) is characterised by

\[
A\,v_i \;=\; \rho_i\,v_i^{\text{next}},
\]

where \(v_i^{\text{next}}\) is *the same direction evaluated at the next point*  
(and \(\rho_i\!\sim\!e^{\lambda_i}\) is an irrelevant stretching factor).  
The direction is **carried forward without rotating into another sub-space**.  
So in a single constant matrix example a CLV is nothing but an eigenvector.

---

#### 2 What a singular vector does instead
Take the SVD of that same \(A\):

\[
A \;=\; U\,\Sigma\,V^{\!\top},
\qquad
\Sigma=\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1\ge\dots\ge\sigma_d).
\]

* **Right singular vector** \(v^{(r)}_i\) (column of \(V\))  
  satisfies \(A\,v^{(r)}_i=\sigma_i\,u^{(l)}_i\).
* **Left  singular vector** \(u^{(l)}_i\) (column of \(U\))  
  satisfies \(A^{\!\top}u^{(l)}_i=\sigma_i\,v^{(r)}_i\).

Unless \(A\) happens to be **normal** (\(A^{\!\top}A=AA^{\!\top}\)) the two
vectors are *different*.  
Hence \(A\) maps the right singular direction to a *new* direction—
still orthogonal to all other images, but **rotated** relative to the
original.

---

#### 3 Why that breaks covariance on the next step
Iterate once more:

\[
A^2\,v^{(r)}_i
  = A\bigl(\sigma_i\,u^{(l)}_i\bigr)
  = \sigma_i\,A\,u^{(l)}_i
  = \sigma_i\,\bigl(A\,u^{(l)}_i\bigr).
\]

The vector \(A\,u^{(l)}_i\) is *not* aligned with \(u^{(l)}_i\) again, so after two steps the direction has already drifted away from the one you started with.  
A CLV, by contrast, keeps landing inside its own one-dimensional
sub-space at every step.

---

#### 4 Geometric picture (2-D example)

```
eigen-basis           singular-basis
      ^y                    ^y
      |                     |
Av---↗ |          Av(r)----↗|     (changes direction)
      |A v_r         A u_l  |
      +-----> x            +-----> x
       v_r                   u_l
```

* The eigenvector \(v\) is simply stretched/contracted along itself.
* The right singular vector \(v_r\) is stretched the most, **but** it is
  rotated onto the (left) vector \(u_l\).  
  Maximum stretch **≠** direction invariance.

---

#### 5 Bottom-line rule (pure linear-algebra wording)

* **Eigenvector:** \(A\,e = \lambda\,e\)  
  direction preserved  ⇒ good candidate for a Lyapunov sub-space.

* **Right singular vector:** \(A\,v_r = \sigma\,u_l\)  
  direction changes     ⇒ cannot be a Lyapunov direction except in the
  special case \(u_l=v_r\) (i.e. when \(A\) is symmetric/normal).

So the covariant Lyapunov vectors are **invariance-oriented**, while the
SVD vectors are **stretch-optimised and orthogonal**.  
Those are fundamentally different linear-algebra objectives, and only
when a matrix is already diagonal in an orthonormal basis (normal) do
the two notions coincide.
can the jacobian be diagonalizable in the general case?

thoughts.content: To answer the user's question: The Jacobian matrix, which represents the flow of a time-varying system, can be diagonalizable at every point, but not generally. For non-symmetric real matrices, diagonalizability isn't typical. In smooth systems, it's possible, but not common — defective matrices are rare. While there might be pointwise diagonalizability, the Jacobian isn't usually simultaneously diagonalizable across the entire trajectory. The key factor here is that local linearizations depend on a time-varying flow and aren't diagonalized by a fixed basis unless the system behaves in a specific, linear way.

parts:
### Short answer  
A **single** Jacobian matrix \(J=Df(x)\) is often diagonal-isable in the *ordinary* linear-algebra sense (especially over \(\mathbb C\)), but for a nonlinear dynamical system what matters is the **whole family** \(\{J=D\Phi^{t}_{x}\}_{t,x}\).  That *cocycle* is **almost never simultaneously diagonal-isable**, and therefore you cannot keep one fixed basis in which every step is a diagonal matrix.  Hence the need for Lyapunov and covariant constructions.

---

## 1 Diagonalising an individual Jacobian

* **At a fixed point \(x\).**  
  A generic real matrix has all eigenvalues simple ⇒ it is diagonal-isable over \(\mathbb C\).  Over \(\mathbb R\) you may still need 2×2 Jordan blocks for complex-conjugate pairs, but “defective’’ (non-diagonal-isable) matrices are a measure-zero exception.

So if you freeze the system at one point in state space, diagonalisation is **usually possible** (modulo complex coordinates).

---

## 2 Why this does **not** solve the dynamical problem

The dynamics uses **products** of Jacobians:

\[
D\Phi^{t}_x
   = J\bigl(\Phi^{t-1}x\bigr)\dots J\bigl(\Phi^1x\bigr)\,J(x).
\]

Two key facts:

1. **Matrices at successive times almost never commute.**  
   Even if every \(J\) is individually diagonal-isable, you cannot choose one basis that diagonalises *all* of them unless they commute—and that happens only in trivial, integrable situations (linear flow, pure scaling, etc.).

2. **Eigen-bases vary with \(x\).**  
   The eigenvectors of \(J(x)\) and \(J(\Phi^{\tau}x)\) point in different directions, and between them the flow rotates vectors out of each earlier eigenspace.

Because of (1) and (2) the product \(D\Phi^{t}_x\) generically becomes a **full, non-normal matrix**, so no fixed coordinate system keeps it diagonal for all \(t\).

---

## 3 Connection to Lyapunov theory

* **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** are designed precisely for this non-commuting situation: they give an *invariant splitting* that is mapped into itself step by step, but they are **not orthogonal** and change continuously with \(x\).

* **Singular vectors (from an SVD)** supply an *orthogonal* basis that maximises stretch over a *finite* interval, but after one more step those directions rotate, so an SVD basis cannot stay diagonal either.

Thus diagonalising each Jacobian is not enough; what you need is a time-dependent, covariant basis—hence the multiplicative-ergodic theorem and its Oseledets splitting.

---

## 4 Special cases where diagonalisation *does* work

| Situation | Why diagonalisation is possible |
|-----------|----------------------------------|
| **Linear system** \(x_{n+1}=A x_n\) with a diagonal-isable \(A\) | All Jacobians equal ⇒ one eigenbasis works forever. |
| **Symmetric gradient flow** | Each \(J\) is symmetric ⇒ it has an orthonormal eigenbasis; the flow is pure stretching, no rotation. |
| **Commuting family** \(J(y)J(z)=J(z)J(y)\) for all \(y,z\) | There exists a basis that diagonalises every member simultaneously (spectral theorem for commuting normal matrices). Rare in nonlinear chaos. |

Outside such exceptional structures the answer to “can we diagonalise the Jacobian in general?” is **no**, and that is why we rely on Lyapunov exponents, flags, and covariant vectors instead of ordinary eigen-decompositions.
Is there a more general fact about non commuting matrices being diagonalizable?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about simultaneous diagonalizability of non-commuting matrices. Generally, only pairwise commuting diagonalizable matrices over an algebraically closed field can be simultaneously diagonalized. This is tied to concepts like Schur decomposition and Jordan canonical form. Non-commuting matrices are unlikely to be simultaneously diagonalizable, but if they form a solvable Lie algebra, they may be triangularizable. So, two diagonalizable but non-commuting matrices can be diagonalized individually, but not simultaneously.

To answer the user’s question: commuting matrices that are diagonalizable can be simultaneously diagonalized because they share common eigenvectors. If they don’t commute, they cannot be simultaneously diagonalized, though they might still be diagonalizable individually. The key idea is that commuting ensures shared eigenspaces, but non-commuting matrices mix actions and eliminate the possibility. However, if there’s degeneracy (like repeated eigenvalues), the diagonalization might be trivial, but simultaneous diagonalization is generally impossible without commuting.

parts:
### The key linear-algebra fact

> **Simultaneous diagonalisation ⇔ pairwise commutation (for diagonalisable matrices over \(\mathbb C\)).**

More precisely:

* Let \(\mathcal S=\{A_1,\dots,A_m\}\subset M_{d}(\mathbb C)\).
* Suppose every \(A_j\) is diagonalisable (has a complete set of eigenvectors).

Then the following statements are equivalent.

1. There exists one invertible matrix \(P\) such that \(P^{-1}A_jP\) is diagonal for **every** \(j\).
2. Every pair in \(\mathcal S\) commutes: \(A_jA_k=A_kA_j\) for all \(j,k\).

If the matrices do **not** commute, a single basis making them all diagonal **cannot exist** (except for the vacuous case where some matrix is a scalar multiple of the identity, which commutes with everything).

---

### Why commuting is necessary

If \(P^{-1}A_jP\) and \(P^{-1}A_kP\) are both diagonal, the diagonal matrices obviously commute, and conjugation preserves commutators, so \(A_j\) and \(A_k\) commute.

Conversely, if the matrices commute **and** are each diagonalisable, you can diagonalise them one by one while staying inside the common eigenspaces of those already done; eventually you obtain a basis that diagonalises them all.  (This is a standard induction-on-dimension argument.)

---

### What “non-commuting but diagonalisable” looks like

Two diagonalisable matrices can each be diagonalised **individually**, yet still fail to share a common eigenbasis.  Example in \(\mathbb R^{2}\):

\[
A=\begin{pmatrix}2&0\\0&1\end{pmatrix},\quad
B=\begin{pmatrix}1&1\\0&1\end{pmatrix}.
\]

* Both are diagonalisable over \(\mathbb C\) (in fact \(A\) is already diagonal; \(B\) is diagonal over \(\mathbb C\) because its single Jordan block has size 2 but eigenvalue repeated).
* They do **not** commute, so no single matrix \(P\) can diagonalise them simultaneously.

For a nonlinear flow the Jacobians \(D\Phi^{t}_{x}\) at successive times almost never commute, so this obstacle arises for essentially every trajectory.

---

### What you can still do when they do **not** commute

* **Simultaneous triangularisation.**  
  Lie’s theorem: any *solvable* Lie algebra of complex matrices can be put in upper-triangular form by a single change of basis.  Commutation is not required; solvability is weaker.

* **Schur decomposition.**  
  Any individual matrix \(A\) admits \(A=Q\,T\,Q^{*}\) with *unitary* \(Q\) and *upper-triangular* \(T\).  Different matrices need different \(Q\)’s unless they commute.

But neither triangularisation nor Schur form keeps the diagonal simplicity you need for “evolve each component independently”; that is why Lyapunov exponents and covariant vectors—rather than eigenvectors—are the right tools for generic, non-commuting cocycles.

---

### Take-away

* **Individual diagonalisation:** always possible for most single matrices.
* **Simultaneous diagonalisation:** requires pairwise commutation (plus diagonal­isability).
* **Non-commuting family:** you cannot eliminate the mixing of directions by any fixed change of basis; this is the root of directional twisting seen in covariant Lyapunov analysis.
what is that first fact called

It’s usually just called the **simultaneous-diagonalisation theorem** (or “commuting–diagonalisable theorem”).  A common textbook phrasing is:

> **Theorem.**  
> If a collection of complex matrices is pairwise commuting and each matrix is diagonalisable, then there exists a single invertible matrix that diagonalises them all—and conversely, if they can be simultaneously diagonalised, they must commute.

When the matrices are additionally **normal** (e.g. symmetric or unitary), this statement is often referred to as the **spectral theorem for commuting normal matrices**.
are the "local" jacobians of the ode always diagonalizable?

thoughts.content: User wants to know if local Jacobians of ODEs are always diagonalizable. In general, no — even over C, matrices can be non-diagonalizable (think nilpotent matrices like [[0,1],[0,0]]). For diagonalizability, conditions like distinct eigenvalues or symmetric Jacobians (from gradient flows) help. In continuous systems near equilibrium, the Hartman-Grobman theorem applies when eigenvalues have distinct non-zero real parts. However, diagonalizability still depends on factors like full eigenvectors, and some cases involve defective matrices.

parts:
No.  
A Jacobian \(J(x)=Df(x)\) at a point \(x\) is simply an arbitrary real (or complex) matrix whose entries vary smoothly with \(x\).  As a linear-algebra object it can be

* **diagonalisable** (most matrices are), or  
* **defective** (lacking a full set of eigenvectors).

Nothing in the ODE framework forces the first case.

---

### When it **is** diagonalisable

* **Distinct eigenvalues** (over \(\mathbb C\)): guarantee a complete eigenbasis.  
  This is the generic situation; a tiny perturbation of \(f\) will almost surely separate repeated eigenvalues.
* **Symmetric (or more generally normal) Jacobian**: happens for gradient flows \(f=-\nabla V\); symmetry ⇒ orthogonal diagonalisation.

---

### When it **is not**

A repeated eigenvalue **plus** rank deficiency yields a Jordan block.  
Example in \(\mathbb R^{2}\):

\[
f(x_1,x_2)=\begin{pmatrix}x_2\\0\end{pmatrix},\qquad
J(0)=\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\0&0\end{pmatrix},
\]

whose Jordan form is non-diagonal.  
Nilpotent, shear-type, or certain control-system Jacobians often have this structure.

---

### Measure-theoretic remark
The set of defective matrices has codimension ≥ 1 in \(M_d(\mathbb R)\); it is “small’’ but not empty.  Smooth vector fields can traverse it, so points where \(J(x)\) is non-diagonalisable are perfectly allowable—and sometimes unavoidable when a bifurcation forces eigenvalues to collide.

---

### Bottom line
“Local Jacobians’’ of an ODE are **usually** diagonalisable but **not always**; diagonalisation fails exactly at points where the linearisation has repeated eigenvalues without enough eigenvectors.

parts:
### “One non-commuting Jacobian ⇒ no **single** diagonalising basis for the whole flow”

A fixed change of coordinates \(P\) could diagonalise **every** tangent map
\(D\Phi^{t}_{x}\) _only if_ all those matrices commute.  
Here is the elementary chain of implications:

| step | statement | why it holds |
|------|-----------|--------------|
| 1 | Suppose there exists an invertible \(P\) such that \(P^{-1}D\Phi^{t}_{x}\,P\) is **diagonal for every time \(t\)**. | assumption |
| 2 | Two diagonal matrices always commute. | scalar entries on the diagonal |
| 3 | Conjugation preserves commutators: \([A,B]=0\;\Longleftrightarrow\;[P^{-1}AP,P^{-1}BP]=0\). | direct computation |
| 4 | Therefore \([D\Phi^{t}_{x},D\Phi^{s}_{x}]=0\) for all \(s,t\). | combine 1–3 |

So *simultaneous* diagonalisation forces the whole family
\(\{D\Phi^{t}_{x}\}_{t\ge0}\) to be pairwise commuting.

---

### Why the family of tangent maps **almost never commutes**

Write the fundamental matrix as an ordered exponential  

\[
D\Phi^{t}_{x}= \mathcal T\exp\!\Bigl(\int_{0}^{t} J\bigl(\Phi^{\tau}x\bigr)\,d\tau\Bigr),
\qquad J(y)=Df(y).
\]

If two Jacobians at different times fail to commute,

\[
\bigl[ J(\Phi^{\tau_1}x),\,J(\Phi^{\tau_2}x) \bigr]\neq0,
\]

their non-commutation propagates into the time-ordered exponential,
and the resulting matrices \(D\Phi^{t}_{x}\) and \(D\Phi^{s}_{x}\)
inherit non-commutation for generic \(s\neq t\).
(One sees this immediately from the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff expansion.)

Because a nonlinear flow moves through different regions of phase space,
different Jacobians are almost never identical; lacking any special symmetry
they fail to commute, and the corresponding tangent maps fail to commute.

---

### Conclusion in plain linear-algebra language

* **Individual diagonalisation** – at each *fixed* time \(t\) you *can*
  pick a basis that diagonalises \(D\Phi^{t}_{x}\).
* **Simultaneous diagonalisation** – a **single** basis working for
  *all* times would require pairwise commutation of the entire family.
  One non-commuting pair is enough to rule this out.

Hence, for a generic nonlinear ODE the mismatch of Jacobians at different
times guarantees that **no fixed coordinate system can keep every
\(D\Phi^{t}_{x}\) diagonal.**  
That is exactly why we need the Oseledets / covariant-Lyapunov machinery:
it provides a *time-dependent* frame that is mapped into itself even
though a global diagonalisation is impossible.
ah so the real trouble is that the eigenbasis is meaningless because it would just rotate indefinitely.

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Exactly—that’s the core issue.

* **At each instant** you can diagonalise the *current* Jacobian \(J(t)=Df\bigl(\Phi^{t}x_0\bigr)\); its eigen-basis exists and tells you how perturbations split **right then**.

* **A moment later** the system has moved to \(\Phi^{t+\Delta t}x_0\); the new Jacobian is, in general, a *different* matrix with a *different* eigen-basis, unrelated to the old one unless the two Jacobians commute. As the trajectory wanders, the sequence of eigen-bases twists continuously (often chaotically).

Because the linear updates you actually apply are *products* of these non-commuting Jacobians,

\[
D\Phi^{t+\Delta t}_{x_0}
      =J(t+\Delta t)\,J(t)\,D\Phi^{t}_{x_0},
\]

no single static basis can keep every product diagonal—or even upper-triangular—through time.  In a fixed coordinate frame the tangent dynamics therefore look like a combination of stretching *and* incessant rotations (“shear”), so the momentary eigen-directions do **not** track the directions that matter asymptotically.

### What solves the problem

* **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** supply a *time-dependent* basis that is mapped into itself: each vector is carried to the corresponding vector at the next point, merely rescaled.  They are the natural replacement for a global eigen-basis when matrices do not commute.

* **Finite-time singular vectors / QR bases** give orthogonal directions that maximise stretch over a chosen window, but you must recompute them at every step because they rotate just like the eigen-vectors.

So yes—the trouble with relying on the instantaneous eigen-basis is precisely that it keeps rotating, making it “meaningless’’ for following perturbations over more than an infinitesimal time.  The covariant Lyapunov construction is designed to follow the flow’s twisting automatically.
if you could diagonalize the flow in principle (acknolwedging that the vectors are meaningless) would the eigenvalues still be related to the singular values and thus the lyapunov exponents?

thoughts.content: To answer: diagonalization often refers to trying to simultaneously diagonalize tangent maps. When it comes to a single matrix, eigenvalues indicate the rate of growth along invariant directions, but only if the matrix is diagonalizable or normal. Singular values show the growth in terms of magnitude. For non-normal matrices, eigenvalues don't directly imply growth rates, but singular values — which are derived from the eigenvalues of \(A^T A\) — correspond to growth in norms, linked to Lyapunov exponents.

parts:
### One matrix first: eigen-values vs. singular-values  

For a **single** matrix \(A\)

* **Eigen-values** \(\lambda_i\) tell how vectors **on invariant lines** scale:  
  \(A e_i=\lambda_i e_i\).
* **Singular-values** \(\sigma_i\) tell the **largest stretch factors** in orthogonal directions:  
  they are the square-roots of the eigen-values of \(A^{\!*}A\).

Relationship:

| matrix type | \(|\lambda_i|\) compared with \(\sigma_i\) |
|-------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **normal** (e.g. symmetric, unitary) | \(\sigma_i=|\lambda_i|\) exactly |
| **non-normal** | \(\sigma_i\ge|\lambda_i|\); the gap can be arbitrarily large |

So if \(A\) is already diagonal in an **orthonormal** basis (normal case), eigen-values and singular-values carry the same growth information; otherwise singular-values dominate.

---

### Now a **flow** (products of many Jacobians)

Write the fundamental matrix over time \(t\)

\[
D\Phi^{t}_{x_0}=A_{t-1}\,A_{t-2}\dots A_{0},
\qquad A_{n}=Df\!\bigl(\Phi^{n}x_0\bigr).
\]

The \(i\)-th **Lyapunov exponent** is

\[
\lambda_i^{(\text{Lya})}
   =\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi^{t}_{x_0}\bigr).
\]

---

### Suppose (hypothetically) we could **diagonalise every step**

Assume each \(A_n\) is diagonal-isable and we manage to write

\[
A_n = P_n\,D_n\,P_n^{-1},
\quad
D_n=\operatorname{diag}(\mu_{1,n},\dots,\mu_{d,n}),
\]
with the change-of-basis matrices \(P_n\) **not blowing up or collapsing** too fast
(“tempered’’ in multiplicative-ergodic jargon).

Then

\[
D\Phi^{t}_{x_0}
   =P_{t-1}\,D_{t-1}\,(P_{t-1}^{-1}P_{t-2})\,D_{t-2}\dots D_{0}\,P_0^{-1}.
\]

Even after diagonalising each factor, the middle products  
\(C_{n}=P_{n}^{-1}P_{n-1}\) are generally **non-diagonal**, i.e. rotations/
shears that re-mix the diagonal directions.  
They are the linear-algebra trace of the *non-commutation* of successive Jacobians.

#### If those coupling matrices happened to be **bounded and nearly diagonal**  
(the exceptional, quasi-integrable case), then

* \(|\mu_{i,n}|\) would dominate,
* the logarithmic time-average \(\tfrac1t\sum\log|\mu_{i,n}|\) would equal
  the Lyapunov exponent, and  
* eigen-values \(\mu_{i,n}\) and singular-values \(\sigma_i\) would deliver the **same** exponents.

#### In the generic case  
\(C_n\) injects extra stretch; singular-values pick up that stretch,
whereas \(|\mu_{i,n}|\) do not.  
Hence

\[
\lambda_i^{(\text{Lya})}\;=\;\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i
\;\;\ge\;\;
\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\sum_{n=0}^{t-1}\log|\mu_{i,n}|,
\]

with strict inequality whenever the shear/rotation produced by
\(C_n\) supplies additional growth.

---

### Intuitive punch-line  

*Diagonalising every instant does **not** neutralise the mixing between instants.*  
The shears coming from the non-commuting change-of-basis matrices add
extra stretching that shows up in singular-values and therefore in the Lyapunov exponents.  
Only in the very special situation where **all Jacobians commute (or remain normal in the same orthonormal basis)** do eigen-values, singular-values, and Lyapunov exponents coincide.
And is the real trouble with the singular vectors that they also infintiely rotate and thus the limit as t->\infty wouldn't make sense?

thoughts.content: The issue with singular vectors is that, as time approaches infinity, they don’t simply converge. Instead, the right singular vectors tend to converge to a "flag" — not a single vector. As time goes on, they rotate within subspaces, influenced by degeneracies and Lyapunov exponents. Particularly, when exponents are simple and separate, there’s more convergence. However, in cases with degeneracies, flipping and chaotic rotation can happen within these subspaces.

The right singular vectors may converge, but they don’t necessarily match the CLVs. They align with the fastest CLV exponentially, but remain orthogonal to slower ones. When there's multiplicity or degeneracy, they rotate to satisfy the orthogonality constraint. The definition of these vectors depends heavily on the time window, and as the window shifts, the vector changes too. There’s no single vector at t → ∞, but rather a sequence of flags. So, rotation is just one factor, but the lack of invariance complicates things.

parts:
Not quite.  The deeper issue is **lack of covariance**, not just endless rotation.

---

### What happens to the finite-time singular vectors

Fix a base point \(x_0\) and consider the Jacobian over an interval of length \(T\)

\[
A_T=D\Phi^{T}_{x_0}=U_T\,\Sigma_T\,V_T^{\!\top}.
\]

* \(V_T=[v^{(r)}_{1,T},\dots,v^{(r)}_{d,T}]\) – right singular vectors,
* \(U_T=[v^{(l)}_{1,T},\dots,v^{(l)}_{d,T}]\) – left  singular vectors.

---

#### 1 As \(T\to\infty\) (horizon fixed at \(0\))

* **Leading vector.**  
  If the top Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_1\) is simple, then  
  \(v^{(r)}_{1,T}\to v_1(x_0)\) exponentially fast; it *does* converge.

* **Lower vectors.**  
  For \(i>1\) the entire *orthonormal block*
  \(\operatorname{span}\{v^{(r)}_{1,T},\dots ,v^{(r)}_{i,T}\}\)
  converges to the *flag* \(F_i^{+}(x_0)=\bigoplus_{j\le i}E_j(x_0)\),  
  but the individual vectors can keep swivelling inside that subspace
  when eigenvalue gaps are small or degenerate.  
  Rotation is a symptom of the **orthogonality constraint**, not a
  failure of the limit of the *subspace*.

So the limit “makes sense’’ but gives you only the flags, not the single
covariant directions \(E_i\) for \(i\ge2\).

---

#### 2 Slide the window one step

Let \(w_i(T)=v^{(r)}_{i,T}\) and move to time \(T+\Delta T\):

\[
A_{T+\Delta T}=D\Phi^{\Delta T}_{\Phi^{T}x_0}\,A_T.
\]

Even if \(w_i(T)\) has converged, its image under \(D\Phi^{\Delta T}\)
is **not aligned with** \(w_i(T+\Delta T)\); you would have to run a new
SVD to restore orthogonality.  
This is what “no covariance’’ means.

---

### Why covariant Lyapunov vectors (CLVs) are different

A CLV \(v_i(x)\) satisfies

\[
D\Phi^{\Delta t}_{x}\,v_i(x)=\rho_i(x,\Delta t)\,v_i(\Phi^{\Delta t}x),
\]

so it simply rescales, with *no* rotation into other subspaces.  
Hence:

| Property | Singular vectors | Covariant vectors |
|----------|------------------|-------------------|
| Orthogonal? | yes (by construction) | no |
| Covariant?  | no | **yes** |
| Long-\(T\) limit gives | forward/backward flags \(F_i^{\pm}\) | exact subspaces \(E_i\) |

To recover the CLVs you must **combine** the forward flag
(\(V_T\) or a QR basis) with the backward flag (\(U_T\) or adjoint‐QR),
using the intersection \(E_i = F_i^{+}\cap F_i^{-}\).

---

### Bottom line

* Finite-time singular vectors do converge (in subspace sense) as
  \(T\to\infty\); the problem is **they are not mapped into themselves**
  by the flow, so you cannot march them forward without re-orthogonalising.
* That non-covariance, not mere rotation, is why singular vectors are
  inadequate as Lyapunov directions and why the covariant construction
  is needed.
Is it true that v_i^\top A u_i = \sigma_i?

thoughts.content: I’m addressing whether \( v_i^\top A u_i = \sigma_i \). In SVD, we have \( A = U \Sigma V^T \), so \( A v_i = \sigma_i u_i \) and \( u_i^\top A = \sigma_i v_i^T \). From this, \( u_i^\top A v_j = \sigma_i \delta_{ij} \), leading to the concept that \( v_i^\top A u_i = \sigma_i v_i^\top u_i \), where \( v_i^\top u_i = \cos \theta_i \), the angle between the singular vectors. So this expression isn’t always 1, unless \( v_i \) and \( u_i \) are aligned.

parts:
No. The only universal “matrix element = singular value” identity is  

\[
u_i^{\top}A\,v_j \;=\;\sigma_i\,\delta_{ij}\quad
\bigl(U^{\top}AV=\Sigma\bigr),
\]

i.e. **left** vector on the left, **right** vector on the right.

For the quantity you wrote we have

\[
v_i^{\top}A\,u_i
   \;=\;v_i^{\top}\bigl(Au_i\bigr)
   \;=\;v_i^{\top}\bigl(\sigma_i\,u_i^{\prime}\bigr)
   \;=\;\sigma_i\,v_i^{\top}u_i ,
\]

because \(Au_i=\sigma_i\,u_i^{\prime}\) where \(u_i^{\prime}=A u_i/\sigma_i\)
is the same left singular vector (unit-length).  
The scalar \(v_i^{\top}u_i=\cos\theta_i\) is the cosine of the angle
between the *right* and *left* singular directions; generically
\(|\cos\theta_i|<1\).

So

\[
\boxed{\,v_i^{\top}A\,u_i=\sigma_i\,\cos\theta_i\,},
\]

and it equals \(\sigma_i\) **only** when the two singular directions
coincide (\(\theta_i=0\)), which happens precisely when \(A\) is
**normal** and the left and right singular bases are the same
(e.g. symmetric positive-definite, orthogonal, or any commuting-normal
matrix).
Is it true that u_i^\top A v_i = \sigma_i?

thoughts.content: The user asked about the equation \( u_i^\top A v_i = \sigma_i \) related to SVD. It holds true for normalized singular vectors with positive values. Given the standard SVD, we have \( A v_i = \sigma_i u_i \) and \( u_i^\top A = \sigma_i v_i^\top \), leading to \( u_i^\top A v_i = \sigma_i \) because \( u_i^\top u_i = 1 \). This is valid for non-zero singular values and assumes orthonormal vectors. If the singular value is zero, the result does not hold.

parts:
Yes. For a real SVD  

\[
A \;=\;U\,\Sigma\,V^{\!\top},\qquad
U=[u_1,\dots,u_d],\;V=[v_1,\dots,v_d],\;
\Sigma=\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1,\dots,\sigma_d),
\]

the singular vectors are orthonormal: \(u_i^{\!\top}u_j=v_i^{\!\top}v_j=\delta_{ij}\).

Because \(A v_i=\sigma_i u_i\) we have  

\[
u_i^{\!\top}A v_i
   = u_i^{\!\top}(\sigma_i u_i)
   = \sigma_i\,u_i^{\!\top}u_i
   = \sigma_i.
\]

Equivalently, using the factorisation directly:

\[
u_i^{\!\top}A v_i
  = e_i^{\!\top}\,U^{\!\top}U\,\Sigma\,V^{\!\top}V\,e_i
  = e_i^{\!\top}\Sigma e_i
  = \sigma_i,
\]

where \(e_i\) is the \(i\)-th standard basis vector.  
More generally,

\[
u_i^{\!\top}A v_j = \sigma_j\,\delta_{ij}.
\]

(In the complex case replace \({}^{\!\top}\) by the conjugate transpose \({}^{*}\).)

thoughts.summary: Clarifying Lyapunov Exponents and Singular Values
thoughts.content: The user seems to be suggesting that singular values, which can be interpreted as the norm of \( A v_i \), should allow for computation of Lyapunov exponents without subspace decomposition. However, this isn't quite accurate. Singular vectors depend on the chosen horizon \( n \), and only the top singular vector represents the correct exponent. The other vectors correspond to subordinate exponents and need to be recomputed at each step. For proper analysis, we need subspaces or re-orthonormalization to accurately compute covariant vectors.

parts:
Not quite. Let’s unpack the two statements carefully.

---

### 1  Finite-time SVD fact  
For any **fixed** matrix \(A\) with right singular vector \(v_i\) and corresponding left singular vector \(u_i\),

\[
A\,v_i=\sigma_i\,u_i,\qquad 
\|v_i\|=\|u_i\|=1\;\Longrightarrow\;
\|A\,v_i\|=\sigma_i .
\]

So for that single linear map you can indeed read the singular value straight from the norm of \(A v_i\).

---

### 2  Lyapunov exponent definition  
For a nonlinear flow (or a non-autonomous linear cocycle) the object whose growth you measure is the **product of Jacobians** along a trajectory:

\[
A_n(x_0)=D\Phi_{x_{n-1}}\,D\Phi_{x_{n-2}}\dots D\Phi_{x_0},
\qquad x_k=\Phi^k(x_0).
\]

The \(i\)-th Lyapunov exponent at \(x_0\) is

\[
\lambda_i
=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n \log\|A_n(x_0)\,v\|,
\]
with \(v\) chosen **inside the \(i\)-th Oseledets subspace \(E_i(x_0)\).**

---

### 3  Why a single singular vector does **not** fix \(\lambda_i\)

If you take the SVD of **one** product \(A_n\):

\[
A_n=U_n\,\Sigma_n\,V_n^{\!\top}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
A_n v^{(r)}_{i,n}=\sigma_{i,n} u^{(l)}_{i,n},
\]

then \(\|A_n v^{(r)}_{i,n}\|=\sigma_{i,n}\) **for that \(n\).**

But to turn this into a Lyapunov limit you would have to keep the *same* starting vector while you let \(n\to\infty\). The trouble is:

1. **The singular basis depends on \(n\).**  
   \(v^{(r)}_{i,n}\) is not the same vector as \(v^{(r)}_{i,n+1}\).
2. **No covariance.**  
   \(A_{n+1}\,v^{(r)}_{i,n}\) is *not* aligned with \(v^{(r)}_{i,n+1}\).  
   After just one more Jacobian factor, the image leaks into faster directions, and its growth rate drifts toward \(\lambda_1\).

Unless you recompute the SVD at every step (which is what QR/SVD
algorithms do for finite-time analysis) a fixed singular vector does **not** stay in the right subspace.  In the limit it almost always inherits the largest exponent.

---

### 4  Role of the Oseledets subspaces  

The Oseledets decomposition

\[
\mathbb R^d
  =E_1(x_0)\oplus\cdots\oplus E_k(x_0)
\]

is the only time-independent choice of subspaces with the property

\[
A_n(x_0)\,E_i(x_0)=E_i(x_n)
\quad\text{and}\quad
\|A_n v\|\sim e^{\,n\lambda_i}\|v\|\;(v\in E_i).
\]

Pick \(v\) in \(E_{i+1}\) and the growth rate is \(\lambda_{i+1}\); pick it with even the tiniest component in \(E_i\) and the faster rate \(\lambda_i\) eventually dominates.  **That invariance is what the SVD vectors lack.**

---

### 5  Summary

* \(\|A v_i\|=\sigma_i\) is perfectly true **for one matrix**.  
* Lyapunov exponents ask for growth under an **entire sequence** of
  non-commuting matrices.  
* To get \(\lambda_i\) you must start in the **covariant subspace
  \(E_i\)**; a single finite-time singular vector does not stay there, so the subspace construction is essential.

In short, the formula \(\|A v_i\|=\sigma_i\) is a snapshot; Lyapunov
theory is a time-lapse, and the snapshot vectors don’t keep pointing in
the right direction as the camera keeps rolling.

parts:
Yes, for **one fixed time-interval**

\[
A=D\Phi^{T}_{x},\qquad 
A\,v_i^{(r)}=\sigma_i\,u_i^{(l)},\qquad 
\|A v_i^{(r)}\|=\sigma_i ,
\]

so the singular value is literally the stretch of its right singular
vector.  
But that **does not** make a Lyapunov‐vector formula redundant, because
the SVD vectors depend on the *window length \(T\)* whereas a Lyapunov
direction must depend **only on the phase point \(x\)** and remain
*covariant* for **all** \(T\).

---

### 1 What the SVD gives you

*Right singular vector (time \(T\))* \(v_i^{(r)}(T,x)\)

* grows at rate \(\displaystyle
  \frac1T\log\|A\,v_i^{(r)}\|=\frac1T\log\sigma_i(T,x)\);
* but is tied to that specific horizon: at the next step one must
  **re-diagonalise** because \(D\Phi^{\Delta t}_{\Phi^{T}x}\,v_i^{(r)}(T,x)\)
  is generally **not** proportional to
  \(v_i^{(r)}(T+\Delta t,\Phi^{\Delta t}x)\).

Hence the map  
\((x,T)\mapsto v_i^{(r)}(T,x)\) is **not covariant**.

---

### 2 What the multiplicative-ergodic theorem asks for

A **covariant Lyapunov vector (CLV)** \(v_i(x)\) satisfies  

\[
D\Phi^{\Delta t}_{x}\,v_i(x)=\rho_i(x,\Delta t)\,v_i\!\bigl(\Phi^{\Delta t}x\bigr)
\quad\text{for all }\Delta t,
\]

and its growth rate is  

\[
\lambda_i=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\log\|D\Phi^{T}_{x}\,v_i(x)\|,
\]

*the same \(v_i(x)\) for every horizon*.  
That vector sits in the Oseledets sub-space \(E_i(x)\), constructed as

\[
E_i(x)=F_i^{+}(x)\,\cap\,F_i^{-}(x)
\quad\text{(intersection of forward and backward flags)}.
\]

A single SVD (or a single forward QR pass) gives **only** the forward
flag \(F_i^{+}\); without the backward flag you cannot isolate
\(E_i(x)\) once \(i>1\).

---

### 3 Where the SVD *does* recover a Lyapunov number

For any \(i\)

\[
\lambda_i \;=\;\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\log\sigma_i(T,x)\,,
\]

so one can extract the **exponent** from the singular values alone.  
What it cannot do is give a **time-independent direction**.  
After each time-step the right singular basis rotates inside
\(F_i^{+}\); for \(i\ge2\) this rotation never settles unless the system
is degenerate (commuting/normal).

---

### 4 Summary in one line

* \(\|A\,v_i^{(r)}\|=\sigma_i\) is a snapshot statement.  
* Lyapunov theory needs a vector **independent of \(T\)** and mapped into
itself by the flow; singular vectors fail that covariance requirement.
The sub-space (flag-intersection) construction supplies the missing
property and turns a sequence of rotating SVD frames into the fixed
covariant Lyapunov directions.

parts:
Below is a “nuts-and-bolts’’ summary that separates three different goals— an orthogonal basis, a time-independent basis, and the stretching factors (= Lyapunov exponents).  Once you keep those three aims distinct the apparent contradictions disappear.

---

## 1 What you can always get

| Quantity | How you obtain it | Orthogonal? | Depends on the time window \(T\)? | Use for exponents? |
|----------|------------------|-------------|-----------------------------------|--------------------|
| **Right/left singular vectors** \(V_T(x),U_T(x)\) | SVD of the Jacobian over the chosen window \(A_T=D\Phi^{T}_x\) | **Yes** | **Yes** (must recompute for every new \(T\)) | **Yes**: \(\displaystyle \lambda_i=\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\log\sigma_i(T)\) |
| **QR (Gram–Schmidt) basis** \(Q_T(x)\) | Standard algorithm used in Lyapunov-exponent codes | **Yes** | **Yes** | **Yes** (diagonals of the \(R\) matrices) |
| **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** \(v_i(x)\) | Intersection of forward & backward flags (Ginelli, Kuptsov algorithms) | No | **No** (at a fixed point \(x\) it is the same for every horizon) | Optional—not needed if you only care about exponents |

---

### Take-away for exponents only  
If all you want are the numbers  
\[
\lambda_i=\lim_{T\to\infty}\tfrac1T \log\sigma_i(T,x)
\]
then any **orthogonal time-dependent basis** (SVD *or* QR) is enough.  
You repeatedly orthonormalise, accumulate the logarithms of the
stretch factors \(\sigma_i\) (or the \(R\)-diagonal entries), divide by elapsed time, and the limit gives the Lyapunov spectrum.  
Covariant vectors are **not** required for that task.

---

## 2 Why the orthogonal basis must change with \(T\)

If the Jacobians at two consecutive instants do **not** commute (the generic nonlinear case)

\[
D\Phi^{\Delta t}_{\Phi^{T}x}\;D\Phi^{T}_x
   \;\neq\;
D\Phi^{T}_x\;D\Phi^{\Delta t}_{\Phi^{T}x},
\]

then the right singular vectors that diagonalise the product over
\([0,T]\) will *not* diagonalise the product over
\([0,T+\Delta t]\).  
Hence an orthogonal “stretch-maximising’’ basis is **necessarily a
function of the time window**.  Nothing is wrong with that—it is just
what the mathematics says.

---

## 3 Why dropping orthogonality buys you “time-independence”

* At each phase-space point \(x\) the **covariant** direction
  \(v_i(x)\) is uniquely defined (up to scale) and **does not
  depend on how long a window you looked at**.  
  Once you have \(v_i\) at \(x\), the flow itself transports it to the
  next point:
  \[
    D\Phi^{\Delta t}_x\,v_i(x)=\rho_i\,v_i(\Phi^{\Delta t}x).
  \]
* To obtain those directions you must relinquish orthogonality, because
  the invariant splitting twists; orthogonalising would mix the
  covariant subspaces at every step.

So **yes**: sacrificing orthogonality gives you a basis that is
“window-independent’’ (defined only by the state).  
But that basis still *varies along the trajectory*—it is attached to the
moving point, not frozen once and for all in the original coordinates.

---

## 4 Which tool to use when

* **Just the Lyapunov exponents**  
  ⇒ run the classical QR/SVD algorithm, keep re-orthonormalising, average the log-stretch values.  Fast, stable, no covariant vectors needed.

* **Invariant directions (CLVs)**  
  ⇒ perform the two-pass Ginelli / Kuptsov procedure (or any
  forward-backward flag-intersection method).  
  Necessary only if you need *directions* (e.g.\ for shadowing, stable/unstable manifolds, or sensitivity analysis).

---

### Bottom-line answer to your question

*There is always an orthogonal basis, but it must be updated with \(T\).  
Giving up orthogonality yields a horizon-independent covariant basis, useful for geometric insight but *not* required to compute the stretching factors themselves.*

Not quite.  The subtlety is **when** you pick the right singular vectors and **how long** you keep using them.

---

### 1 Set-up: one finite window

Fix a point \(x\) and a horizon \(T\).  
Let  

\[
A_T(x)=D\Phi^{T}_{x}=U_T\,\Sigma_T\,V_T^{\!\top},
\qquad
V_T=[v^{(r)}_{1,T},v^{(r)}_{2,T},\dots].
\]

* \(v^{(r)}_{i,T}\) is orthonormal **for this particular \(T\)**.
* \(A_T\,v^{(r)}_{i,T}= \sigma_i(T,x)\,u^{(l)}_{i,T}\).

---

### 2 What happens if you keep those vectors and go farther in time

Advance another \(\tau\):

\[
D\Phi^{T+\tau}_{x}
  =D\Phi^{\tau}_{\Phi^{T}x}\;A_T(x).
\]

Acting on \(v^{(r)}_{i,T}\):

\[
D\Phi^{T+\tau}_{x}\,v^{(r)}_{i,T}
   = D\Phi^{\tau}_{\Phi^{T}x}\,\bigl(\sigma_i u^{(l)}_{i,T}\bigr).
\]

The new factor \(D\Phi^{\tau}_{\Phi^{T}x}\) **rotates** \(u^{(l)}_{i,T}\)
into a fresh direction; generically the result is a mixture of **all**
current singular directions.  
Therefore the growth rate of that original vector is **not** just
\(e^{\lambda_i\tau}\); its dominant component quickly shifts to the
fastest Lyapunov direction present.

---

### 3 Asymptotic truth

*If* you choose \(T\) large enough that  
\(v^{(r)}_{i,T}\) has essentially converged to the Oseledets subspace
\(E_i(x)\), then:

* its image under **any** further time \(\tau\) lies in
  \(E_i(\Phi^{\tau}x)\), merely rescaled;
* its norm grows like \(e^{\lambda_i\tau}\) (up to sub-exponential
  factors).

But you only get that behaviour after taking a **large-\(T\) limit**
first; with a finite \(T\) the vector is still contaminated by faster
components, which soon dominate.

---

### 4 Linear combinations

Given a vector  
\(w=\sum_{i}c_i\,v^{(r)}_{i,T}\)

* the piece with the **largest** non-zero \(c_i\) (smallest index \(i\))
  dominates the long-time growth:
  \[
     \|D\Phi^{\tau}_{\Phi^{T}x}w\|\sim
     e^{\lambda_{j}\tau},\quad
     j=\min\{i:c_i\neq0\}.
  \]
* all slower components (\(i>j\)) become negligible.

---

### 5 Bottom line

* **Right singular vectors** give instantaneous,
  orthogonal “stretch directions’’ for a *chosen* window length \(T\).
* They are **not** fixed Lyapunov directions; propagated further, they
  mix and their norms follow whichever exponent is fastest among their
  current components.
* Only after letting \(T\to\infty\) first (so \(v^{(r)}_{i,T}\to E_i\))
  do you obtain vectors whose subsequent growth is exactly
  \(e^{\lambda_i\tau}\).

parts:
It depends on which **point in phase space** you intend λ to be attached to.

---

### Finite-time Lyapunov exponent (FTLE)

For a flow map \(\Phi^{t}\) write the Cauchy-Green tensor  

\[
C_t(x_0)=\bigl(D\Phi^{t}_{x_0}\bigr)^{\!\top}\!D\Phi^{t}_{x_0},
\qquad x_0:=x(0).
\]

The FTLE field is usually defined as  

\[
\boxed{\;
\lambda_{\max}(x_0,t)=\frac1{t}\,
 \log\sqrt{\lambda_{\text{max}}\bigl(C_t(x_0)\bigr)}
\;} .
\]

So the natural arguments are **“initial condition, horizon’’**:
\(\lambda(x_0,t)\).

If you write \(\lambda\bigl(x(t),t\bigr)\) you are evaluating **the same
scalar** but labelling the grid point by the advected position
\(x(t)=\Phi^{t}(x_0)\).  That is fine as long as you state that you have
switched to a Lagrangian (co-moving) coordinate, but it hides the fact
that the quantity depends on where the trajectory started.

---

### Infinite-time (Oseledets) exponent

For the asymptotic exponent

\[
\lambda_i(x_0)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1{t}\log
               \bigl\|D\Phi^{t}_{x_0}v\bigr\|
\]

the base point is again the initial position \(x_0\).  Along the orbit
\(x(t)=\Phi^{t}(x_0)\) you can certainly speak of
\(\lambda_i\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\), but that just means “the Lyapunov
exponent evaluated **at the point reached after time \(t\)**.”  The
function itself is always defined with respect to *its own* base point.

---

### Rule of thumb

* **Eulerian viewpoint (plots, grids):** write \(\lambda(x_0,t)\).
* **Trajectory-label viewpoint:** write \(\lambda\bigl(x(t),t\bigr)\) but
  remember it is the *same value* that was determined by the initial
  position \(x_0\).

So if the symbol \(x\) in your equation already denotes the **current**
state \(x(t)\), then yes—strictly speaking the FTLE should be written
\(\lambda(x_0,t)\) or \(\lambda\!\bigl(\Phi^{-t}x,t\bigr)\).  If \(x\)
was meant to be the **initial** point all along, your original
\(\lambda(x,t)\) is fine; just be explicit in the surrounding text.
