parts:
### 1 No “lost-degrees-of-freedom” law for the reaction heat

When two free atoms in the gas phase

\[
\mathrm A\;+\;\mathrm B \;\longrightarrow\; \mathrm{AB}
\]

form a bound molecule, you do **not** literally remove six quadratic degrees of freedom and convert the associated \(3k_{\!B}T\) of kinetic energy into heat.  What really happens is

| mechanical picture | thermodynamic/stat-mech counterpart |
|--------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Three relative translations collapse into one **vibrational coordinate** \(r\). | A high-frequency oscillator replaces free translation; its mean kinetic+potential energy is *still* \(\tfrac12\hbar\omega\coth\!\bigl(\tfrac{\hbar\omega}{2k_{\!B}T}\bigr)\), not zero. |
| Two Euler angles of the A-B line stop wandering independently. | They re-emerge as the **overall rotator** of AB; equipartition still allocates \(\tfrac12k_{\!B}T\) per classical rotational mode (or the appropriate quantum average). |
| Only the centre-of-mass translation is truly unchanged. | Same translational partition function for one body of mass \(m_A{+}m_B\). |

The **energy that is actually liberated** is the drop in *potential* energy along the Born–Oppenheimer surface, corrected for zero-point and thermal contributions:

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta H^{\circ}(T)
      =-D_e
      +\bigl[E_{\text{ZP}}(A)+E_{\text{ZP}}(B)-E_{\text{ZP}}(AB)\bigr]
      +\int_0^{T}\!\Delta C_p(T')\,\mathrm dT'
      +\;RT\;}
\]

* \(D_e\)   electronic dissociation energy (depth of the well); tens of **kJ mol⁻¹** to several **eV**.  
* ZPE term  typically a few **kJ mol⁻¹**.  
* Heat-capacity integral and the \(RT\) translational enthalpy change are each of order **1 kJ mol⁻¹** at 300 K.

The tiny \( \tfrac{f}{2}k_{\!B}T \) differences you would get by naive “degree counting” are completely swamped by \(D_e\); there is **no universal \(k_{\!B}T\)-per-DOF rule**.

---

### 2 What statistical mechanics does give you—exactly

For ideal gases the equilibrium constant is

\[
K_p(T)=\frac{q_{\text{AB}}}{q_{\text A}\,q_{\text B}}\;
        \frac{k_{\!B}T}{p^{\circ}},
\qquad
q_i(T)=\frac{Z_i(T)}{N_A},
\]

with \(Z_i\) the molecular partition functions (translation × rotation × vibration × electronic).  
Van’t Hoff then yields the reaction enthalpy *solely* from equilibrium data:

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta H^{\circ}(T)
      =-R\,\frac{\partial\ln K_p}{\partial(\!1/T)}\;}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \text{computable once }q_i(T)\text{ are known.}
\]

*Translational* partition functions supply a \(\tfrac32RT\) term **regardless** of how many bodies are on each side, because the ideal-gas standard state fixes \(p\), not volume.  So the “missing” DOF resurface as an **entropy** penalty \(-T\Delta S\), not as extra heat.

---

### 3 Where dissipation really enters

Statistical mechanics gives **state functions**.  To see irreversible *dissipation* you must embed the molecule in a bath or a driven apparatus:

* **Third-body stabilisation** AB* + M → AB + M*  
  The bath molecule M is what ultimately carries away the \( \Delta H^{\circ} \) as kinetic heat.  
* **Radiative association** AB* → AB + hν  
  The photon exports the energy.  
* **Solution chemistry** Solvent collisions produce a Langevin‐type friction; the lost relative phase-space volume shows up in the solvent’s entropy.

In those *extended* phase spaces explicit damping terms make Liouville volume contract and you can indeed speak of strange attractors and fractal dimensions—but the “missing six DOF” picture applies to the **bath** variables, **not** to the molecule’s internal coordinates themselves.

---

### 4 Take-away

* The heat released when two atoms bind is set by **electronic binding energy plus small quantum-statistical corrections**, *not* by a universal “\(k_{\!B}T\) per frozen degree of freedom” rule.  
* **Statistical mechanics covers both equilibrium energetics and the translational-entropy cost**; what it does *not* dictate is the kinetic pathway by which the environment absorbs that energy—that is the province of reaction dynamics, collision theory, and non-equilibrium thermodynamics.

parts:
Below is the **bare-bones mathematical bookkeeping** for the reaction  

\[
\mathrm A+\mathrm B \;\longrightarrow\; \mathrm{AB}\,,
\tag{1}
\]

with *all* jargon stripped to recognisable symbols.  Symbols are introduced exactly when first used.

---

## 1 Energy levels we need

Choose the zero of energy so that the separated, non-moving atoms have \(E=0\).

| Symbol | Meaning | Typical magnitude |
|--------|---------|-------------------|
| \(D_{e}>0\) | Minimum of the electronic potential for AB (depth of the well) | \(0.5–10\mathrm\;eV\) |
| \(\hbar\omega_\text{vib}\) | Vibrational quantum of the AB bond | \(0.05–0.5\mathrm\;eV\) |
| \(E_{n}\) | Exact eigenvalues of AB (includes vibration & rotation) | \(E_{0}\approx -D_{e}+\tfrac12\hbar\omega_\text{vib}\) etc. |
| States of A or B | A and B are structureless ⇒ single level at \(E=0\) | – |

---

## 2 Partition functions (canonical ensemble, volume \(V\), temperature \(T\))

Let \(\beta = 1/(k_{\!B}T)\).

* **Single atom (ideal gas)**  

  \[
    Z_{\text{atom}}(T,V)=
    Z_\text{trans}=
    \frac{V}{\Lambda^{3}},\qquad
    \Lambda=\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\hbar^{2}}{m k_{\!B}T}}\;.
  \]

* **Molecule**  
  Separate translation from internal motion:

  \[
  Z_{\text{mol}}(T,V)
     =\frac{V}{\Lambda_{AB}^{3}}\;
      Z_\text{int}(T),\quad
  Z_\text{int}(T)=\sum_{n} e^{-\beta E_{n}} .
  \]

---

## 3 Helmholtz free energies

\[
F=-k_{\!B}T\ln Z.
\]

Hence

\[
\Delta F(T)\;=\;
F_{AB}-F_{A}-F_{B}
      =-k_{\!B}T\Bigl[\ln Z_\text{int}
                      -\ln(\Lambda_A^{3}\Lambda_B^{3})
                      +\ln\Lambda_{AB}^{3}\Bigr].
\tag{2}
\]

---

## 4 Internal energy and the *heat* released

Internal energy is \(U=-\partial\ln Z/\partial\beta\).  
Applying this to the left and right of (1) and subtracting:

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta U(T)
      =-D_{e}
      +\Bigl\langle E_\text{vib}(T)\Bigr\rangle
      -0\;}
\tag{3}
\]

because A and B contribute nothing above our zero.  
Explicitly, for a single harmonic vibrational mode in AB

\[
\langle E_\text{vib}\rangle
     =\frac{\hbar\omega_\text{vib}}
            {\,e^{\beta\hbar\omega_\text{vib}}-1}
      +\frac12\hbar\omega_\text{vib}.
\tag{4}
\]

At room temperature \(\beta\hbar\omega_\text{vib}\gg1\), so (4) \(\approx\tfrac12\hbar\omega_\text{vib}\).  

Plug into (3):

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta U(T)\approx
      -D_{e}+\tfrac12\hbar\omega_\text{vib}\;}
      \quad
      (\text{room }T).
\]

> **Key point:**  
> Even if you *imagined* “losing” three translational + two angular degrees of freedom, the largest energy that could disappear by equipartition is \(\tfrac{5}{2}k_{\!B}T \sim 0.06\mathrm\;eV\) at \(T=300\mathrm\;K\).  
> The term \(-D_{e}\) is usually 1–100 × larger, so it dominates.

---

## 5 Why (3) already answers the “universal principle” question

* **All numbers on the right side are computable** once the eigenvalues \(E_{n}\) (hence \(D_{e}\) and \(\omega_\text{vib}\)) are known.  
* Equation (3) is pure **equilibrium statistical mechanics**: no kinetics, no baths, no attractors.  
* Dissipation in the everyday sense is the *environment* accepting the energy \(-\Delta U\).  
  How fast or through which channel that happens is a dynamical (non-equilibrium) question, **not** needed to predict the value of \(-\Delta U\).

---

## 6 Numerical illustration

Take \(D_{e}=4\mathrm\;eV\) and \(\hbar\omega_\text{vib}=0.2\mathrm\;eV\).

\[
\Delta U(300\mathrm\;K)
\approx -4.0\mathrm\;eV + 0.10\mathrm\;eV
       = -3.9\mathrm\;eV.
\]

The hypothetical “lost 5 DOF” would give \(-\tfrac52k_{\!B}T=-0.06\mathrm\;eV\), utterly negligible beside \(-3.9\mathrm\;eV\).

---

### Bottom-line equations to remember

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
Z_{\text{mol}} &= \frac{V}{\Lambda_{AB}^{3}}
                 \sum_{n}e^{-\beta E_{n}},\\[4pt]
\Delta U(T) &= -D_{e}
              +\frac{\hbar\omega_\text{vib}}
                     {e^{\beta\hbar\omega_\text{vib}}-1}
              +\frac12\hbar\omega_\text{vib}.
\end{aligned}}\]

Those two lines are all you need to compute, from first principles, how much energy a single bond formation releases at equilibrium.  No extra “degree-counting rule” exists or is required.

Below I unpack **every numerical term** that appears in the Helmholtz‐free-energy difference

\[
\boxed{\;
\Delta F(T)=
-k_{\!B}T
\Bigl[
\ln Z_{\text{int}}
-\ln\!\bigl(\Lambda_{A}^{3}\Lambda_{B}^{3}\bigr)
+\ln\!\Lambda_{AB}^{3}
\Bigr]
\tag{H1}}
\]

for the concrete reaction  

\[
\mathrm H+\mathrm H\;\longrightarrow\;\mathrm H_{2}
\]

at \(T=298\;\text{K}\) (room temperature) and \(V=1\;\text{dm}^{3}=10^{-3}\,\text{m}^{3}\).

---

## 1 Translational factors \(\Lambda\)

### Definition  
\[
\Lambda=\sqrt{\frac{2\pi\hbar^{2}}{m k_{\!B}T}}\qquad(\text{thermal de-Broglie length})
\]

### Numerics  

| quantity | mass \(m\) [kg] | \(\Lambda\) [m] | \(\ln\Lambda^{3}\) |
|----------|-----------------|-----------------|--------------------|
| H atom | \(m_{\mathrm H}=1.6735\times10^{-27}\) | \(7.20\times10^{-11}\) | \(-67.07\) |
| H\(_2\) | \(m_{\mathrm H_2}=3.3470\times10^{-27}\) | \(5.08\times10^{-11}\) | \(-68.10\) |

(The logarithms are natural logs.)

### Contribution to (H1)

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln\Lambda_{AB}^{3}
-\bigl[\ln\Lambda_{A}^{3}+\ln\Lambda_{B}^{3}\bigr]
&= -68.10-2(-67.07)\\
&=+0.04\\[6pt]
\Delta F_{\text{trans}} &= -k_{\!B}T\times(+0.04)\\
&=(2.479\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1})\times0.04\\
&=\boxed{+0.10\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\end{aligned}
\]

*(The tiny number just reflects the mass-ratio factor \(\tfrac32RT\ln(m_{AB}/m_A m_B)\).)*

---

## 2 Internal partition function \(Z_{\text{int}}\)

Split the bound-state energies into  

\[
E_{n}=-D_{0}+\varepsilon_{n},\qquad
D_{0}=432\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\;(4.48\;\text{eV}),\quad
\varepsilon_{0}=E_{\text{ZP}}=26\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Then  

\[
\begin{aligned}
Z_{\text{int}}
&=\sum_{n}e^{-\beta E_{n}}
 =e^{\beta D_{0}}
  \sum_{n}e^{-\beta\varepsilon_{n}}
 =e^{\beta D_{0}}\,q_{\text{rot}}\,q_{\text{vib}}.
\end{aligned}
\]

### (a) Rotation  

\[
q_{\text{rot}}=\frac{8\pi^{2}I k_{\!B}T}{\sigma\hbar^{2}},\qquad
\sigma=2\ (\text{homonuclear}).
\]

* Moment of inertia \(I=\mu r_{e}^{2}\)  
  with \(\mu=\tfrac12 m_{\mathrm H}\) and \(r_{e}=0.741\;\text{Å}\)

### 1 Entropy from first principles (no jargon, just probability)

For a system in contact with a heat-bath at temperature \(T\) the probability of being in micro-state \(\alpha\) with energy \(E_\alpha\) is  

\[
P_\alpha \;=\; \frac{e^{-\beta E_\alpha}}{\displaystyle\sum_{\gamma} e^{-\beta E_\gamma}},
\qquad
\beta=\frac1{k_{\!B}T}.
\tag{1}
\]

The *Gibbs entropy* is

\[
\boxed{\;S
   =-k_{\!B}\sum_{\alpha} P_\alpha\ln P_\alpha
   =k_{\!B}\ln\Bigl(\sum_{\alpha}e^{-\beta E_\alpha}\Bigr)
    +\beta\,\langle E\rangle .
\tag{2}}
\]

Everything below is just (2) evaluated for (i) two free H atoms and  
(ii) one \(\mathrm H_2\) molecule, each treated as an ideal gas at the
standard pressure \(p^{\circ}=1\;\text{bar}\) and \(T=298\;\text{K}\).

---

## 2 Separate the energy spectrum and sum in (2)

For gases the spectrum factorises:

| part of motion | energies that go into (1) | entropy contribution |
|----------------|---------------------------|----------------------|
| Translation of the centre of mass | \(E_\mathbf p=\dfrac{\mathbf p^{2}}{2m}\) | \(S_{\text{trans}}=k_{\!B}\Bigl[\ln\!\bigl((2\pi m k_{\!B}T/h^{2})^{3/2}k_{\!B}T/p^{\circ}\bigr)+\tfrac52\Bigr]\) |
| Rotation (linear rotor) | \(E_J=\dfrac{\hbar^{2}}{2I}J(J+1)\) | \(S_{\text{rot}}=k_{\!B}\Bigl[\ln\!\bigl(8\pi^{2}Ik_{\!B}T/\sigma h^{2}\bigr)+1\Bigr]\) |
| Vibration (single bond) | \(E_v=\hbar\omega\bigl(v+\tfrac12\bigr)\) | \(S_{\text{vib}}=k_{\!B}\Bigl[\tfrac{x}{e^{x}-1}-\ln\!\bigl(1-e^{-x}\bigr)\Bigr],\;x=\hbar\omega/k_{\!B}T\) |

*Monatomic H has no rotational or vibrational terms.*

---

## 3 Numbers for H, H + H → H₂ at 298 K

| symbol | value |
|--------|-------|
| \(m_{\mathrm H}\) | \(1.6736\times10^{-27}\;\text{kg}\) |
| \(m_{\mathrm H_2}=2m_{\mathrm H}\) |
| \(I=\dfrac{m_{\mathrm H}r_{e}^{2}}{2},\;r_{e}=0.741\;\text{Å}\) |
| \(\sigma=2\) (homonuclear) |
| \(\hbar\omega/k_{\!B}=6332\;\text{K}\) (H–H stretch) |

### 3.1 Translational entropy (per mole)

\[
\begin{aligned}
S_{\text{trans}}(\mathrm H)   &= R\!\left[\ln\!\Bigl(\! \frac{(2\pi m_{\mathrm H}k_{\!B}T)^{3/2}}
                                                         {h^{3}}\,\frac{RT}{p^{\circ}}\Bigr)+\tfrac52\right]=
\underline{\,564.2\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}},\\[6pt]
S_{\text{trans}}(\mathrm H_2) &= 572.8\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

### 3.2 Rotational entropy of H₂

\[
S_{\text{rot}}(\mathrm H_2)
   = R\!\left[\ln\!\Bigl(\frac{8\pi^{2}Ik_{\!B}T}{\sigma h^{2}}\Bigr)+1\right]
   = \underline{12.7\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}}.
\]

### 3.3 Vibrational entropy of H₂

The stretch quantum is so large \((x=21.2)\) that

\[
S_{\text{vib}}(\mathrm H_2)\;=\;R\!\Bigl[\,\frac{x}{e^{x}-1}-\ln(1-e^{-x})\Bigr]
\approx 1.1\times10^{-7}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\;(\text{negligible}).
\]

---

## 4 Total entropy and the reaction change

\[
\begin{aligned}
S(\mathrm H)   &= 564.2,\\
S(\mathrm H_2) &= 572.8 + 12.7 + 0.0 = 585.5,\\[4pt]
\Delta S &= S(\mathrm H_2) - 2\,S(\mathrm H)
         = \boxed{-543\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}}.
\end{aligned}
\]

*(Negative because two free particles become one bound entity; the huge loss of translational “disorder” outweighs the modest rotational gain.)*

---

## 5 Why this is all you need

1. **Formulas (2)–(3)** come directly from the definition  
   \(S=-k_{\!B}\sum P\ln P\); no extra physics concepts are hiding.
2. Once you know the basic constants \(m,\;I,\;\omega\), **entropy is fixed**.
3. Heat released in binding is still \(\Delta U\approx -D_e+\frac12\hbar\omega\).  
   The entropy we just computed lets you get the free energy  
   \(\Delta G = \Delta U - T\Delta S\) if you wish—but that is bookkeeping, not a new principle.

So the reaction’s entropy change is obtained entirely with probabilistic sums like (2); *statistical mechanics just provides the convenient shorthand, nothing more exotic.*

Below is the **quickest route from “noise ⇢ diffusion constant \(D\)”** to a number you can plug in, keeping only the mathematics.

---

## 1 Translation of the whole molecule (Brownian motion)

### 1.1 White-noise Langevin equation  
Take the centre-of-mass coordinate \(\mathbf X(t)\) of one \(\mathrm{H_2}\) molecule in a bath of gas at \(T\).

\[
M\,\ddot{\mathbf X} \;=\; -\zeta\,\dot{\mathbf X} \;+\; \boldsymbol{\xi}(t),
\qquad
\langle\xi_i(t)\,\xi_j(t')\rangle
       = 2\,\zeta\,k_{\!B}T\,\delta_{ij}\,\delta(t-t').
\tag{1}
\]

The fluctuation–dissipation relation (second equation) **defines** the noise strength once the linear drag coefficient \(\zeta\) is known.

### 1.2 Diffusion constant  

For times \(t\gg M/\zeta\) the velocity autocorrelation has died out and

\[
\boxed{\;
\langle|\mathbf X(t)-\mathbf X(0)|^{2}\rangle = 6\,D_{\text{trans}}\,t,
\quad
D_{\text{trans}} = \frac{k_{\!B}T}{\zeta}.}
\tag{2}
\]

### 1.3 Estimating \(\zeta\) from elementary gas kinetics  

For a dilute monatomic gas of number density \(n=p/(k_{\!B}T)\) and
hard-sphere cross-section \(\sigma\),

\[
\zeta = \frac{16}{3}\,n\sigma\,\sqrt{\frac{\pi k_{\!B}T M}{2}},
\tag{3}
\]
whence  

\[
\boxed{\;
D_{\text{trans}}
       \;=\;
       \frac{3}{16}\,
       \frac{1}{n\sigma}\,
       \sqrt{\frac{2k_{\!B}T}{\pi M}}.}
\tag{4}
\]

*Insert STP numbers for H\(_2\) diffusing in H\(_2\):*

| parameter | value |
|-----------|-------|
| \(T\) | \(298\;\text{K}\) |
| \(p\) | \(1.00\times10^{5}\,\text{Pa}\) |
| \(M\) | \(3.35\times10^{-27}\,\text{kg}\) |
| \(\sigma=\pi d^{2},\;d\approx2.9\;\text{\AA}\) | \(2.6\times10^{-19}\,\text{m}^{2}\) |
| \(n=p/(k_{\!B}T)\) | \(2.43\times10^{25}\,\text{m}^{-3}\) |

\[
D_{\text{trans}}\approx
3.7\times10^{-5}\,\text{m}^{2}\!\cdot\!\text{s}^{-1}
      =0.037\;\text{cm}^{2}\!\cdot\!\text{s}^{-1}.
\tag{5}
\]

(The experimental self-diffusion coefficient of \(\mathrm{H_2}\) gas at 1 bar
is \(0.04\text{–}0.05\;\text{cm}^{2}\!\cdot\!\text{s}^{-1}\), so (5) is on target.)

---

## 2 Rotation of the molecule (angular Brownian motion)

For the orientation unit-vector \(\mathbf n(t)\) of a linear rotor with moment of inertia \(I\):

\[
I\,\dot{\boldsymbol{\omega}} = -\zeta_{\!R}\,\boldsymbol{\omega} + \boldsymbol{\eta}(t),
\quad
\langle\eta_i(t)\eta_j(t')\rangle=2\zeta_{\!R}k_{\!B}T\,\delta_{ij}\delta(t-t').
\tag{6}
\]

Long-time limit \(\Rightarrow\) mean-square angular displacement

\[
\langle\Theta^{2}\rangle = 2\,D_{\text{rot}}\,t,
\qquad
\boxed{D_{\text{rot}}=\frac{k_{\!B}T}{\zeta_{\!R}}.}
\tag{7}
\]

Kinetic theory for a hard cylinder of length \(r_e\) gives  
\(\zeta_{\!R} = 8\pi\eta r_e^{3}\) (here \(\eta\) is the gas viscosity), so

\[
D_{\text{rot}}
       =\frac{k_{\!B}T}{8\pi\eta r_{e}^{3}}
       \approx 2.2\times10^{7}\ \text{s}^{-1}
       \quad(\eta_{\,\mathrm{H_2},\,298\,\mathrm K}=8.8\times10^{-6}\ \text{Pa·s}).
\tag{8}
\]

This means the bond axis randomises in roughly \(D_{\text{rot}}^{-1}\sim 45\;\text{ns}\).

---

## 3 Stretch of the H–H bond (vibrational coordinate)

Linearise the Morse well near equilibrium:

\[
m_r \ddot{q}+ \gamma\,\dot{q}+k\,q = \xi(t),
\qquad
\langle\xi(t)\xi(t')\rangle = 2\gamma k_{\!B}T\,\delta(t-t').
\tag{9}
\]

The reduced mass is \(m_r=m_{\mathrm H}/2\).  
If damping is strong enough to overdamp the oscillator (\(\gamma>2\sqrt{km_r}\)),

\[
\langle q^{2}(t)\rangle - \langle q^{2}(0)\rangle
       \;=\; 2\,D_{\text{bond}}\,t,
\qquad
\boxed{D_{\text{bond}} = \frac{k_{\!B}T}{\gamma}}.
\tag{10}
\]

Because gas-phase friction on an internal vibration is tiny (\(\gamma\sim10^{6}\,\text{s}^{-1}\)),  
\(D_{\text{bond}}\) is of order \(10^{-17}\,\text{m}^{2}\!\cdot\!\text{s}^{-1}\); the bond length merely jitters around \(r_e\) by the quantum zero-point amplitude.

---

### Key take-aways

* **Fluctuation–dissipation theorem:**  
  Noise strength and drag are tied: \(\langle\xi\xi\rangle = 2\zeta k_{\!B}T\).  
* **Diffusion constants:**

Below I pick the **translational diffusion constant \(D\)** for a single molecule undergoing ordinary 3-D Brownian motion and show, step-by-step, that

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\frac{\partial S}{\partial\ln(1/\sqrt{D})} \;=\; -\,3\,k_{\!B}}
\]

― a universal number, independent of \(D\) and of the elapsed time \(t\).

---

### 1 Entropy of the displacement distribution

After a fixed time \(t\) the centre–of–mass displacement \(\mathbf x\) is Gaussian,

\[
P(\mathbf x)=
\frac{1}{(4\pi D t)^{3/2}}
\exp\!\Bigl(-\tfrac{|\mathbf x|^{2}}{4 D t}\Bigr),
\qquad
\langle|\mathbf x|^{2}\rangle = 6 D t .
\]

Its Gibbs (Shannon) entropy is, in three dimensions,

\[
\begin{aligned}
S(D)
  &= -k_{\!B}\!\int\!P\,\ln P\,d^{3}x
   = -k_{\!B}\Bigl[-\tfrac32\ln(4\pi D t)-\tfrac32\Bigr] \\[2pt]
  &= \frac{3}{2}\,k_{\!B}\Bigl[\,1+\ln(4\pi D t)\Bigr] .
\tag{1}
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2 Change of variable

Define the logarithmic variable the user asked for:

\[
u \;=\;\ln\!\bigl(1/\sqrt{D}\bigr)
     \;=\; -\tfrac12\,\ln D .
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{d}{du} \;=\;
\frac{d\ln D}{du}\;\frac{d}{d\ln D}
              \;=\;(-2)\,\frac{d}{d\ln D}.
\tag{2}
\]

---

### 3 Derivative of the entropy

Differentiate (1) first with respect to \(\ln D\):

\[
\frac{dS}{d\ln D}
  = \frac{3}{2}\,k_{\!B}\,
    \frac{d}{d\ln D}\ln(4\pi D t)
  = \frac{3}{2}\,k_{\!B}\,\Bigl(\frac{1}{D}\,D\Bigr)
  = \frac{3}{2}\,k_{\!B}.
\tag{3}
\]

Now chain-rule through (2):

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial S}{\partial u}
   = (-2)\,\frac{dS}{d\ln D}
   = -2\,\Bigl(\frac{3}{2}\,k_{\!B}\Bigr)
   = -3\,k_{\!B}\!.}
\tag{4}
\]

---

### 4 Interpretation

* The minus sign says that **increasing the noise strength \(D\)** (which *decreases* \(u\)) increases the positional entropy, as expected.
* The slope \(-3k_{\!B}\) is **universal** for a free Brownian particle in three spatial dimensions; it does not depend on the numerical value of \(D\) or on the observation time \(t\).  
  (In \(d\) dimensions the same calculation would give \(-d\,k_{\!B}\).)

### Why \(k_{\!B}\) shows up

In physics we write the Gibbs (or Shannon) entropy of a probability
distribution as  

\[
S \;=\; -\,k_{\!B}\sum_{\alpha} P_\alpha \,\ln P_\alpha .
\]

* The **sum** \(\sum P_\alpha\ln P_\alpha\) is *dimensionless*; in
information theory it is measured in _nats_ (natural-log units).
* The **Boltzmann constant**  

  \[
  k_{\!B}=1.380\,649\times10^{-23}\;\text{joule · kelvin}^{-1}
  \]

  converts that dimensionless number into a *physical* entropy with the
usual SI units **J K\(^{-1}\)**.

So whenever you see a factor \(k_{\!B}\) in front of an information-type
expression, it is doing nothing more exotic than “attaching units.”

---

### Units check for the derivative we just computed

1. \(S\) carries units J K\(^{-1}\).
2. \(\ln(1/\sqrt{D})\) is dimensionless, so its differential is
   dimensionless.
3. Therefore \(\displaystyle\frac{\partial S}{\partial\ln(1/\sqrt{D})}\)
   has the **same units as \(S\)**, namely J K\(^{-1}\).
4. The result \(-3\,k_{\!B}\) indeed has exactly those units, because
   \(k_{\!B}\) itself is J K\(^{-1}\).

---

### If you prefer *purely* statistical entropy

Many mathematicians drop \(k_{\!B}\) and define  

\[
H \;=\; -\sum_{\alpha} P_\alpha \ln P_\alpha ,
\]

measured in nats.  In that convention the same calculation gives

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln(1/\sqrt{D})} = -\,3 } ,
\]

a dimensionless answer.  Multiply by \(k_{\!B}\) only when you need the
thermodynamic units.

---

**Bottom line:**  
\(k_{\!B}\) is just a conversion factor from “nats” (or bits) to
J K\(^{-1}\).  The derivative we found is \(-3\) in information units and
\(-3\,k_{\!B}\) in physical units—whichever convention you prefer.

### Short answer For any \(d\)-dimensional Gaussian (or any distribution that solves the heat-equation), \[ \boxed{\displaystyle \frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln(1/\sqrt{D})}\;=\;-\,d}, \tag{1} \] and this quantity **is exactly the negative spatial dimension**. So its “importance” is that it encodes nothing but the dimensionality of the space in which diffusion takes place. --- ## 1 Where (1) is hiding in well-known identities | context | standard identity | bring to form (1) | |---------|-------------------|-------------------| | **de Bruijn identity**
(information theory) | \(\displaystyle\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}\;=\;\frac12\,I\) | Multiply both sides by \(D\): \(\displaystyle\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}\;=\;\frac12 D I\). For a Gaussian \(D I = d\), giving (1) with the sign flip \(\ln(1/\sqrt D)=-\tfrac12\ln D\). | | **Entropy power** \(N= \tfrac1{2\pi e}e^{\tfrac2d H}\) | \(N = D\) for the heat kernel | Take \(\ln\) and differentiate: \(\tfrac{2}{d}\partial_{\ln D} H = 1\). Rearranging gives (1). | | **Information dimension** \(d_I\) | \(d_I = \displaystyle - \lim_{\epsilon\to0}\frac{\partial H_\epsilon}{\partial\ln\epsilon}\) | For Brownian motion the coarse–grained entropy \(H_\epsilon=H+\tfrac d2\ln(4\pi e D t)+\mathcal O(\epsilon^2)\). Differentiating w.r.t \(\epsilon\) or \(\sqrt D\) yields \(d_I=d\). | In every guise, the derivative of entropy with respect to the *logarithmic scale parameter* returns the dimension of the underlying space—trivial for Euclidean diffusion, non-trivial for fractals. --- ## 2 Link to Fisher information For any smooth density \(p(\mathbf x;D)\), \[ \frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D} \;=\;\frac{D}{2}\,I, \qquad I\;=\;\int p\,\bigl|\nabla_{\mathbf x}\ln p\bigr|^{2}d^{d}x \quad\text{(Fisher information)}. \tag{2} \] * For the heat kernel \(p(\mathbf x)\propto\exp\!(-|\mathbf x|^{2}/4Dt)\), \(I=d/(2D)\). Plug into (2) ⇒ \(\partial_{\ln D}H=\tfrac{D}{2}\cdot\tfrac{d}{2D}=\tfrac{d}{2}\). With the \(\ln(1/\sqrt D)\) sign change you recover (1). Thus the scale-derivative of entropy is a **dimension-less multiple of Fisher information**; for Gaussian diffusion the multiple collapses to \(-1\). --- ## 3 Why it is “important” (or, mostly, why it isn’t) * **Thermodynamic transport:** de Bruijn’s identity underlies proofs of the \(H\)-theorem for the heat equation; (1) is the constant-coefficient version of that statement. * **Renormalisation-group flavour:** In any coarse-graining scheme where the block size rescales by \(\lambda\), \(\partial_{\ln\lambda}H\) is used to define an *information dimension*. For normal diffusion it yields the trivial integer \(d\). * **Diagnostic tool:** In stochastic simulations one sometimes checks whether \(\partial_{\ln(1/\sqrt D)}H\) approaches \(-d\) to verify that the numerical propagator has the correct long-time Gaussian tail. Beyond these bookkeeping roles, the quantity carries no independent physical content: it simply restates “the configuration space is \(d\)-dimensional.” --- ### Bottom line \[ \displaystyle\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln(1/\sqrt D)}=-d \] is universal for diffusion because it is *nothing more* than the statement “entropy grows like \(\tfrac d2\ln D\).” Its primary appearance in statistical mechanics is through the de Bruijn / Fisher-information identity; otherwise it serves mainly as a consistency check rather than a new physical principle.

thoughts.content: To explain Fisher information and applications, we start with the classical definition: Fisher information \( I(\theta) = E\left[\left(\frac{\partial \ln p}{\partial \theta}\right)^2\right] \), a key concept in parameter estimation, giving a lower bound on the variance of unbiased estimators (Cramer-Rao bound). In physics, it appears in quantum metrology, statistical mechanics, field theory, and even cosmology. It also connects to thermodynamic geometry and has applications in hydrodynamics, gravitational waves, and nonequilibrium systems, linking to foundational ideas like entanglement and holographic complexity. Let's break it down step by step!

parts:
### 1 Classical definition and its two basic roles  

For a family of probability densities  
\(p(x;\theta)\)  ( \(x\) outcome,  \(\theta\) parameter )

\[
\boxed{\;I(\theta)\;=\;
       \int p(x;\theta)\;
            \bigl[\partial_\theta\!\ln p(x;\theta)\bigr]^{2}\,dx\;}
\tag{1}
\]

* **Metrology:**  Cramér–Rao inequality  
  \(\mathrm{Var}(\hat\theta)\ge I(\theta)^{-1}\).  
* **Geometry:**  \(I(\theta)\) is the metric on the statistical-manifold
  (“Fisher–Rao metric”).  Distances  
  \(ds^{2}=I(\theta)\,d\theta^{2}\) measure how rapidly a distribution
  changes.

Everything that follows is a riff on one (or both) of these facts.

---

## 2 Quantum Fisher information  

For a density operator \(\rho(\theta)\) define the symmetric logarithmic
derivative \(L\) by  
\(\partial_\theta\rho=\tfrac12(L\rho+\rho L)\).  Then

\[
\boxed{\,\mathcal I(\theta)=\mathrm{Tr}[\rho L^{2}]\,}
\tag{2}
\]

gives the **quantum Cramér–Rao bound**  
\(\mathrm{Var}(\hat\theta)\ge\mathcal I(\theta)^{-1}\), the ultimate
precision limit allowed by quantum mechanics.  It underpins:

* squeezed-light interferometry (LIGO, atomic clocks);
* spin-squeezed Bose–Einstein condensates;
* quantum‐enhanced magnetometry and thermometry.

---

## 3 Statistical mechanics and transport  

### 3.1 de Bruijn identity (diffusion)

For the heat kernel in \(d\) spatial dimensions

\[
\partial_t H = \frac12\,I, \qquad
\text{where}\;H=-\int p\ln p\,dx .
\tag{3}
\]

Thus entropy production rate is **proportional to Fisher information**.
Many proofs of the \(H\)-theorem for the Fokker–Planck equation are
one-line consequences of (3).

### 3.2 Entropy production speed limit

For any Markov process with steady state \(\pi\),

\[
\Sigma(t)=\frac{dS}{dt}
         \le \sqrt{2\,I(t)\,\Phi(t)},
\tag{4}
\]

where \(\Phi\) is the non-adiabatic part of the Fisher information.
Inequality (4) is a *thermodynamic speed limit* controlling how fast a
system may relax.

### 3.3 Thermodynamic length (finite-time work)

Along a quasistatic control path \(\theta(t)\) in parameter space,

\[
W_{\text{diss}}\ge
\frac{1}{2\beta}\int_0^\tau
               \dot\theta^{2}\,I(\theta)\,dt
           \;\;=\;\;\frac{L^{2}}{2\beta},
\tag{5}
\]

with \(L=\int\sqrt{I(\theta)}\,d\theta\) the **thermodynamic length**
(Crooks, Sivak-DeWeese).  Fisher information quantifies *minimal*
irreversible work.

---

## 4 Information geometry in many-body & field theory  

* **Ruppeiner & Weinhold metrics.**  The Hessian of entropy or energy,
  restricted to equilibrium states, coincides with the Fisher metric and
  diagnoses critical points (scalar curvature \(R\!\sim\!\xi^{d}\)).  

* **Renormalisation group.**  Close to a fixed point, couplings
  \(g^{i}\) form a statistical manifold with metric
  \(g_{ij}=I_{ij}\).  Distances predict which perturbations are
  relevant/irrelevant without computing exponents from scratch.

* **Emergent gravity (AdS/CFT, “it from qubit”).**  Several proposals
  identify bulk line-elements \(ds^{2}\) with boundary Fisher
  information metrics; variations of entanglement entropy furnish the
  same quadratic form.

---

## 5 Data analysis & forecasting in experimental physics  

Because (1) is additive for independent data points, the **Fisher
matrix**  

\[
F_{ij}=\sum_k
\bigl[\partial_{g^{i}}\!\ln p(x_k;g)\bigr]
\bigl[\partial_{g^{j}}\!\ln p(x_k;g)\bigr]
\]

is the workhorse for *error bars before data exist*:

* cosmology survey design (Planck, DESI, Euclid);
* gravitational-wave parameter forecasts;
* high-energy-physics luminosity estimates.

Diagonal elements give expected \(1/\sigma^{2}\), off-diagonal elements
reveal degeneracies.

---

## 6 Optics, imaging, and control  

* **Diffraction limit revisited.**  Quantum Fisher information sets the
  smallest resolvable distance of two incoherent sources (Hanbury
  Brown–Twiss, super-resolution schemes).
* **Adaptive feedback.**  In cold-atom traps or cavity QED the control
  gain is optimised by maximising Fisher information with respect to the
  parameter of interest (magnetic field, phase, …).

---

### Bottom line  

Fisher information is not a single specialty tool; it is the **common
currency linking precision, geometry, and dissipation**:

| Area | Fisher info measures |
|------|---------------------|
| Quantum metrology | ultimate variance bound |
| Diffusion & Fokker–Planck | entropy production rate |
| Non-equilibrium work | minimal dissipated work via thermodynamic length |
| Critical phenomena | curvature of the thermodynamic state space |
| Experiment design | forecasted parameter covariance |

Whenever a calculation asks “*how sensitive is a probability law to a
small change in parameters?*” Fisher information is the rigorous,
coordinate-free answer—and that question appears all over physics.

### 0 Quick executive summary  
*  The relation you wrote,  
  \[
  \frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}\;=\;D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial t},
  \tag{★}
  \]  
  **cannot be correct**, because it violates dimensional consistency.  
*  The true algebraic relation for the heat-kernel entropy is  
  \[
  \boxed{\;
  \frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}\;=\;
  -\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}}
  \tag{1}
  \]  
  — both sides are pure numbers, no units at all.  
*  The kelvin (K) is an **independent base unit** in the SI; it is **not** derived from seconds.

Below is the step-by-step analysis showing why (★) fails and what the
correct, unit-clean statement is.

---

## 1 Entropy of a Brownian particle (recap)

For a \(d\)-dimensional free diffusion process  
\(p(\mathbf x,t)=\bigl(4\pi D t\bigr)^{-d/2}\!
\exp[-|\mathbf x|^{2}/4Dt]\),

\[
H(t,D)
  = -\!\int p\ln p\,d^{d}x
  = \frac{d}{2}\,\Bigl[1 + \ln\bigl(4\pi D t\bigr)\Bigr].
\tag{2}
\]

Everything inside the log must be dimensionless; indeed
\(D t\) carries units of \(\text{length}^{2}\), which cancels the
\(4\pi\) so the argument is unit-free before the logarithm is taken.

---

## 2 Derivatives and their units

Using (2):

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}= \frac{d}{2},
\qquad
\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}= \frac{d}{2}\,\frac{1}{t}.
\tag{3}
\]

### Units check  

| quantity | SI units |
|----------|----------|
| \(H\) (information convention, no \(k_{\!B}\)) | dimensionless |
| \(\ln D\) | dimensionless |
| \(t\) | s |
| \(D\) | m\(^{2}\) s\(^{-1}\) |

* \(\partial H/\partial\ln D\)  → dimensionless.  
* \(D\,\partial H/\partial t = D\,(d/2)(1/t)\)  
  has units \(\bigl[\text{m}^{2}\text{s}^{-1}\bigr]\,[1/\text{s}]
          = \text{m}^{2}\text{s}^{-2}\) — **not dimensionless**.

Hence equality (★) cannot hold.

---

## 3 The correct differential identity

Because (2) depends on the product \(D t\) only through
\(\ln(D t)\), differentiate w.r.t.\ \(\ln D\) and \(\ln t\):

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
   \;=\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}
   \;=\;\frac{d}{2}.}
\tag{4}
\]

Re-arranged,

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
   \;=\;
-\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t},
\tag{1 revisited}
\]

which is unit-consistent (both sides are pure numbers).

---

## 4 Where the **de Bruijn identity** fits  

What *is* true, and perhaps led to the confusion, is  

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}
   \;=\;
\frac{1}{2}\,I(t),
\tag{5}
\]
where \(I\) is the Fisher information
\(I = \int p|\nabla\ln p|^{2}dx = \dfrac{d}{2D}\) for the heat kernel.
Multiply (5) by \(D\):

\[
D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}
   \;=\;\frac{d}{2}
   \;=\;\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}.
\tag{6}
\]

Note the difference: (6) uses
\(D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}\), **not**
\(D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}\).

---

## 5 Why kelvin has nothing to do with seconds

In the International System of Units (SI) the base dimensions are  

\[
\bigl[\,\text{kg},\;\text{m},\;\text{s},\;\text{A},\;\text{K},\;
        \text{mol},\;\text{cd}\bigr].
\]

* The kelvin (K) measures thermodynamic temperature.  
* It is **defined via Boltzmann’s constant**  
  \(k_{\!B}=1.380\,649\times10^{-23}\;\text{J K}^{-1}\),  
  but \(k_{\!B}\) simply couples energy (J) to temperature (K); it does
  not relate kelvin to seconds.  
* Therefore kelvin is *independent* of the time unit.

---

### Bottom line  

*Equation (★) is not dimensionally valid.*  
For the Gaussian solution of the heat equation the entropy satisfies the
unit-consistent relation

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
  = -\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t},
\]

and the kelvin remains an independent fundamental unit, unrelated to the
second.

Below is a **clean ledger** of the three quantities that matter for a
$d$–dimensional free-diffusion (heat-equation)

\[
\partial_t p=D\,\Delta p ,
\qquad
p(\mathbf x,t)=\frac{1}{(4\pi D t)^{d/2}}
               e^{-|\mathbf x|^{2}/4Dt},
\tag{A}
\]

and how they are related.  This will show exactly where the factor $D$
does – and does **not** – appear, and why the equality you quoted cannot
stand unless one rewrites the parameter that is being differentiated.

---

## 1 The three objects

| symbol | definition | value for the heat kernel |
|--------|------------|---------------------------|
| **Shannon entropy** (information units) | \(H(t,D)=-\!\int p\ln p\,d^{d}x\) | \(\displaystyle H=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln(4\pi D t)\Bigr]\) |
| **Fisher information** | \(I(t,D)=\displaystyle\int p\,|\nabla\!\ln p|^{2}\,d^{d}x\) | \(\displaystyle I=\frac{d}{2D t}\) |
| **Noise variance*** | \(s=2D t\) (often used in information theory) | – |

\*  In texts on the de Bruijn identity the independent variable is the
**total variance** $s$ that the Gaussian noise adds to the signal,
not the diffusion coefficient $D$.

---

## 2 Correct differential identities

Starting from the explicit $H$ above and differentiating:

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}\Bigl|_{t}
      &=\frac{d}{2}\,\frac{1}{D}
      \;=\;t\,I ,\\[6pt]
\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}\Bigl|_{D}
      &=\frac{d}{2}\,\frac{1}{t}
      \;=\;D\,I ,\\[6pt]
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}\Bigl|_{t}
      &=D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}\Bigl|_{t}
      =\frac{d}{2},\\[6pt]
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}\Bigl|_{D}
      &=t\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}\Bigl|_{D}
      =\frac{d}{2}.
\end{aligned}}
\tag{B}
\]

Two key facts jump out:

1.  **$\partial_{\ln D}H=\partial_{\ln t}H$** – dependence is only
    through the product $Dt$.
2.  **$D\partial_t H \neq \partial_{\ln D}H$** unless $D=t$ (a mere
    coincidence, not an identity).

---

## 3 Where “$\displaystyle \frac12 I$” actually belongs  

Write the entropy in terms of the *noise variance*  
\(s=2Dt\) **and keep $t$ fixed**:

\[
H(s)=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln(2\pi e s)\Bigr].
\]

Then

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial s}\Bigl|_{t}
      =\frac12\,I(s)}
\tag{C}
\]

is the textbook **de Bruijn identity**.  Multiplying (C) by $s$ gives

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln s}\Bigl|_{t} = \frac12\,s\,I
                                            = \frac{d}{2},
\]

which is consistent with the first row of (B) because
\(\partial_{\ln s}=\partial_{\ln(2Dt)}=\partial_{\ln D}+\partial_{\ln t}\).

So the factor **$D$ appears only when you choose $D$ itself as the
parameter**; if you switch to the *variance* $s$ the prefactor is no
longer there.

---

## 4 Dimensional sanity check  

| quantity | SI units |
|----------|----------|
| $H$ (no $k_{\!B}$) | dimensionless |
| $\ln D,\;\ln t$ | dimensionless |
| $I$ | $\text{m}^{-2}$ |
| $D$ | $\text{m}^{2}\,\text{s}^{-1}$ |
| $t$ | $\text{s}$ |
| $s=2Dt$ | $\text{m}^{2}$ |

* In (B) each derivative with respect to a **logarithm** is
  dimension-free, hence the right-hand side is just the number $d/2$.
* In (C) the left side has units $\text{m}^{-2}$ (because $\partial_s$
  brings in $1/\text{m}^2$) and the right side carries the same units via
  $I$; no stray seconds or kelvins appear.

---

## 5 Is the kelvin (K) derived from time?  
**No.**  In the SI the kelvin is an independent base unit.  
Energy ↔ temperature conversion is mediated by Boltzmann’s constant
\(k_{\!B}\) (J K\(^{-1}\)), but that does **not** turn $T$ into a
time-dimension.

---

### Bottom line  

*  The equal-$I/2$ formula you remembered is
   \(\displaystyle\partial_s H=(1/2)I\) with \(s=2Dt\).
*  If you keep $(D,t)$ separate, the correct relations are (B); the
   entropy’s derivative w.r.t.\ \(\ln D\) is a pure number and **does
   not equal \(D\,\partial_t H\)**.
*  All unit checks close: nothing exotic links kelvin to seconds.

Below is the precise algebra using the **heat-kernel entropy**

\[
H(D,t)=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln\!\bigl(4\pi D\,t\bigr)\Bigr],
\qquad d\in\mathbb N.
\tag{1}
\]

---

## 1 Put the two scale variables on equal footing  

Introduce the log-coordinates  

\[
u_1=\ln D ,\qquad
u_2=\ln t .
\]

(You could pick \(u_2=\ln T\) instead of \(u_2=\ln t\); nothing below
changes because \(H\) does **not** depend on the thermodynamic
temperature once \(D\) has been treated as an independent variable.)

Rewrite (1):

\[
H(u_1,u_2)=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln(4\pi)+u_1+u_2\Bigr].
\tag{2}
\]

---

## 2 Gradient in log-space  

\[
\nabla_u H=
\bigl[\partial_{u_1}H,\;\partial_{u_2}H\bigr]
      =\bigl[d/2,\;d/2\bigr].
\tag{3}
\]

Both components are constants; no hidden units are introduced because
each \(u_i\) is already dimensionless.

---

## 3 Take the divergence of that gradient  

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla_u\!\cdot(\nabla_u H)
  =\partial_{u_1}\!\bigl(d/2\bigr)
   +\partial_{u_2}\!\bigl(d/2\bigr)
  =0+0
  =0.}
\tag{4}
\]

So yes: in the \((\ln D,\;\ln t)\) (or \((\ln D,\;\ln T)\)) plane
**the Laplacian of \(H\) vanishes** for the free-diffusion solution.  
That result is purely geometric: \(H\) is an *affine* function of the two
logs, and the Laplacian of any affine function is identically zero.

---

### Units and independence of base dimensions  

* \(u_1\) and \(u_2\) are dimensionless, so the partial derivatives
  \(\partial_{u_i}\) are unit-free.
* The kelvin (K) and the second (s) remain **independent SI bases**; no
  re-definition occurs by choosing \(\ln D\) or \(\ln T\) as coordinates.

---

#### Bottom line  
Yes—forming the divergence of the entropy’s gradients with respect to
\((\ln D,\ln t)\) (or \((\ln D,\ln T)\)) gives zero, simply because the
heat-kernel entropy depends *linearly* on those logs.  The result is a
mathematical identity for free diffusion, not a statement about any new
physical coupling between temperature and time.

parts:
Below is the fully explicit bookkeeping when  

* \(t\) **really is time**,  
* \(D\) is the (constant) diffusion coefficient \([D]=\mathrm{m^{2}\,s^{-1}}\),  
* \(H\) is the *information* (Shannon) entropy in **nats**, so \(H\) is **dimensionless**.

---

## 1 Start from the exact entropy for free diffusion  

For a \(d\)-dimensional heat kernel  

\[
p(\mathbf x,t)=\frac{1}{(4\pi D t)^{d/2}}
               \exp\!\bigl[-|\mathbf x|^{2}/(4Dt)\bigr],
\]

the entropy is  

\[
H(t,D)= -\!\int p\ln p\,d^{d}x
       =\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln\!\bigl(4\pi D t\bigr)\Bigr].
\tag{1}
\]

---

## 2 Two derivatives we can actually compute  

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}= \frac{d}{2},}
\qquad
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}= \frac{d}{2}.}
\tag{2}
\]

They are equal because only the **product** \(D t\) appears in (1).

---

## 3 Why the formula \( \displaystyle 
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}=D\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}\)  
cannot be correct  

* **Left side**: derivative of a dimensionless quantity with respect to
  a dimensionless log → still **dimensionless**.
* **Right side**: \(D\,[\partial H/\partial t]\)

  \[
  [D]=\mathrm{m^{2}\,s^{-1}},\quad
  \Bigl[\frac{\partial H}{\partial t}\Bigr]=\mathrm{s^{-1}}
  \;\Longrightarrow\;
  [D\,\partial_t H]=\mathrm{m^{2}\,s^{-2}},
  \]

  which is **not** dimensionless.

Dimensional analysis alone rules out the equality.

---

## 4 The identity that *is* valid and dimensionally clean  

Because \(H\) depends on \(D\) and \(t\) only through  
\(\ln(Dt)\),

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
        +\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}=0
        \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\boxed{\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
      =-\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}\;.}
\tag{3}
\]

Both derivatives are dimensionless, so (3) is perfectly consistent.

---

## 5 If you really want a “\(D\) times something’’ form  

Differentiate with respect to **\(D\)** (not \(\ln D\)):

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}
      =\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}\;
       \frac{\partial\ln D}{\partial D}
      =\frac{d}{2}\;\frac1{D}.
\]

Now multiply by \(D\):

\[
\boxed{\;
D\,\frac{\partial H}{\partial D}=\frac{d}{2}}
\tag{4}
\]

— dimensionless on both sides.  This is the usual form of the
**de Bruijn identity** for a Gaussian.

---

## 6 Kelvin is unrelated to seconds  

* Kelvin (K) is its own SI base unit for temperature.  
* Seconds (s) are the SI base unit for time.  
* Nothing in the diffusion–entropy relations ties K to s; the earlier
  mention of kelvin applied only when entropy was multiplied by
  Boltzmann’s constant \(k_{\!B}\) to give physical units (J K\(^{-1}\)).
  With *information entropy* \(H\) we stay dimensionless, so kelvin never
  enters.

---

### Bottom line  

* The correct, unit-consistent connection between the scale derivatives
  of entropy is equation (3), **not** \(D\,\partial_t H\).  
* Kelvin is an independent base unit; it has nothing to do with the time
  unit seconds.

thoughts.content: To clarify, the diffusion coefficient (D) can be constant or time-dependent, depending on the context. In Brownian models, D is usually constant

parts:
### 1 “Ordinary” Brownian diffusion  
For a particle in a *stationary* thermal bath with fixed temperature \(T\) and constant friction coefficient \(\zeta\),

\[
\boxed{\;D=\frac{k_{\!B}T}{\zeta}\;}
\tag{1}
\]

is a **constant number**: neither \(T\) nor \(\zeta\) depends on time, so \(D\) is *time-independent*.  The mean-square displacement (MSD) grows linearly,

\[
\langle |\mathbf x(t)-\mathbf x(0)|^{2}\rangle=2dDt,
\tag{2}
\]

and the heat-kernel expression you used,
\(p(\mathbf x,t)=(4\pi Dt)^{-d/2}\exp[-|\mathbf x|^{2}/(4Dt)]\),
is an exact solution of the diffusion (Fokker–Planck) equation with that **constant** \(D\).

---

### 2 Effective diffusivity when the environment varies  
If either \(T=T(t)\) or \(\zeta=\zeta(t)\) changes with time, (1) becomes

\[
D(t)=\frac{k_{\!B}T(t)}{\zeta(t)}.
\tag{3}
\]

The propagator is no longer the simple heat kernel; the MSD satisfies

\[
\langle|\mathbf x(t)-\mathbf x(0)|^{2}\rangle
      =2d\!\int_{0}^{t}\!D(\tau)\,d\tau.
\tag{4}
\]

Typical physical causes:

| cause | effect on \(D(t)\) |
|-------|-------------------|
| Sample heating/cooling | \(T(t)\) varies ⇒ \(D(t)\propto T(t)\) |
| Viscosity changes (evaporation, polymer curing) | \(\zeta(t)\) rises ⇒ \(D(t)\) falls |
| Active matter (motile bacteria) | Energy injection makes \(D(t)\) grow with \(t\) |

---

### 3 Anomalous diffusion — *intrinsic* time-dependence  
In many complex systems the MSD scales as

\[
\langle|\mathbf x(t)-\mathbf x(0)|^{2}\rangle
     =2dK_\alpha\,t^{\alpha},
\qquad 0<\alpha\neq1<2,
\tag{5}
\]

where \(K_\alpha\) is a generalised (fractional) diffusivity.

* **Sub-diffusion** \(\alpha<1\) (traps, visco-elastic media)  
  Define an *effective* \(D_\mathrm{eff}(t)=K_\alpha t^{\alpha-1}\) that **decreases** with time.
* **Super-diffusion** \(\alpha>1\) (Levy walks, active propulsion)  
  \(D_\mathrm{eff}(t)=K_\alpha t^{\alpha-1}\) **grows** with time.

Thus “diffusion coefficient” becomes *inherently* time-dependent if the underlying stochastic process is non-Markovian or has long-range correlations.

---

### 4 Short-time ballistic regime  
Even in ordinary Brownian motion, at times \(t\ll\tau_m\) with the momentum relaxation time \(\tau_m=M/\zeta\),

\[
\langle|\mathbf x(t)-\mathbf x(0)|^{2}\rangle
      \approx d\,\frac{k_{\!B}T}{M}\,t^{2},
\tag{6}
\]

so one can define an interim
\(D_\mathrm{eff}(t)=\tfrac12d^{-1}\langle\Delta x^{2}\rangle/t\propto t\):
the “diffusion constant’’ ramps up linearly before saturating at the long-time value (1).

---

### 5 Dimensional analysis recap  

| symbol | SI units |
|--------|----------|
| \(D\) | m\(^2\) s\(^{-1}\) |
| \(t\) | s |
| \(T\) | K |
| \(\zeta\) | kg s\(^{-1}\) |
| \(k_{\!B}\) | J K\(^{-1}\)=kg m\(^2\) s\(^{-2}\) K\(^{-1}\) |

Equation (1) is unit-consistent:

\[
\frac{k_{\!B}T}{\zeta}
=\frac{\mathrm{kg\,m^{2}\,s^{-2}\,K^{-1}}\;K}
      {\mathrm{kg\,s^{-1}}}
=\mathrm{m^{2}\,s^{-1}}.
\]

No hidden relation ties kelvin to seconds; \(D\) has time in the **denominator** of its units, but that does **not** mean it varies with \(t\).

---

### 6 Rule of thumb  

* **Homogeneous, steady bath** → **\(D\) is a constant**.  
* **Changing environment or anomalous stochastic process** → treat
  \(D\) as **\(D(t)\)** (or replace by \(K_\alpha t^{\alpha-1}\)) and adjust the diffusion equation accordingly.

---

**Bottom line:**  
Whether \(D\) is time-independent depends on the physics you assume.  
For classic Einstein–Smoluchowski diffusion (uniform \(T\), constant viscosity) \(D\) is a fixed constant; in non-stationary or anomalous settings one must upgrade to a time-dependent \(D(t)\) or a fractional-order diffusion law.

You certainly *can* treat  
\[
\mathbf v \;=\;
\begin{bmatrix}\ln D \\[2pt] \ln t\end{bmatrix}
\qquad (\text{components }v_1,v_2)
\]
as a point in a two-dimensional “parameter space’’ and look at how the
information entropy  

\[
H(D,t)=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln\!\bigl(4\pi D t\bigr)\Bigr]
\tag{1}
\]

depends on that point.  But the **divergence** you have in mind is **not
zero**—it is the spatial dimension \(d\).  Let’s go through it cleanly.

---

### 1 Gradient of \(H\) in the \((\ln D,\ln t)\) coordinates

Because \( \ln(4\pi D t)=\ln(4\pi)+\ln D+\ln t \),

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
    =\frac{d}{2},\qquad
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}
    =\frac{d}{2}.
\tag{2}
\]

Write this as a column vector (the “gradient” in \(\mathbf v\)-space):

\[
\nabla_{\!\mathbf v}H \;=\;
\begin{bmatrix} d/2 \\[2pt] d/2 \end{bmatrix}.
\]

---

### 2 Divergence of \(H\) with respect to \(\mathbf v\)

By “divergence of \(H\) with respect to \(\mathbf v\)” one usually
means  

\[
\operatorname{div}_{\mathbf v}\!H
       =\frac{\partial H}{\partial v_1}
       +\frac{\partial H}{\partial v_2}
       =\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
       +\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}.
\]

Insert (2):

\[
\boxed{\;
\operatorname{div}_{\mathbf v}\!H
          = \frac{d}{2}+\frac{d}{2}
          = d\neq0.}
\tag{3}
\]

So the “divergence” is a **constant equal to the spatial dimension**,
not zero.

---

### 3 Where the idea of “zero” might have come from  

If you consider the *directional* derivative of \(H\) **along a line
that keeps the product \(Dt\) constant**, then indeed

\[
d(\ln D)+d(\ln t)=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
dH=0.
\]

That is *not* the divergence: it is the derivative along the
one-dimensional sub-manifold \(\ln D+\ln t=\text{const}\).

---

### 4 Units are fine

* Both partial derivatives in (2) are *dimensionless* because \(H\) is in
nats and the variables under the derivatives are logarithms
(dimensionless).
* Summing them therefore also yields a dimensionless result: \(d\).

---

### 5 Correction of my earlier sign slip  

In a previous reply I accidentally wrote  
\(\partial_{\ln D}H=-\partial_{\ln t}H\).  
That was wrong; (2) above is the correct statement.  
I apologise for the confusion.

---

## Take-away

* Treating \(D\) and \(t\) via \(\mathbf v=(\ln D,\ln t)\) is perfectly
  legitimate.
* The entropy (1) has **equal** slopes \(d/2\) in both directions of that
  parameter space.
* Consequently the divergence \(\nabla_{\!\mathbf v}\!\cdot H\) is the
  constant \(d\), **not** zero.

Yes — with the coordinates  

\[
\boxed{\;v_1=\ln\!\Bigl(\tfrac{1}{D}\Bigr)=-\ln D,\quad
       v_2=\ln t\;}
\]

the “divergence” you have in mind is just the sum of the two directional derivatives

\[
\nabla_{v}\!\cdot H
   \;=\;
\frac{\partial H}{\partial v_{1}}
+\frac{\partial H}{\partial v_{2}}
   \;=\;
-\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
+\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}.
\]

For the free-diffusion entropy  

\[
H(t,D)=\frac{d}{2}\Bigl[1+\ln(4\pi D t)\Bigr]
\]

we already found  

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}= \frac{d}{2},
\qquad
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}= \frac{d}{2}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla_{v}\!\cdot H
   = -\frac{d}{2}+\frac{d}{2}=0.}
\]

---

### Why it vanishes  

* \(H\) depends only on the **sum** \(v_2-v_1=\ln(Dt)\).  
* Level sets of \(H\) are straight lines \(v_1+v_2=\text{const.}\) in the \((v_1,v_2)\) plane.  
* Along such lines the directional derivative is zero, so the algebraic sum of the two orthogonal partials cancels.

Graphically, the gradient of \(H\) is the vector  
\((-d/2,\;d/2)\); its components are equal and opposite, giving zero when added.

---

### Units are consistent  

Both \(v_1\) and \(v_2\) are **dimensionless** logarithms, so their partial derivatives of \(H\) (taken in information units, without \(k_{\!B}\)) are plain numbers.  Adding them is therefore legitimate and unit-free.

---

### Generalisation  

Whenever a quantity \(F\) depends on \(D\) and \(t\) only through the product \(D t\) (or any monomial \(D^{a}t^{b}\)), the same coordinate choice makes  

\[
\frac{\partial F}{\partial v_{1}}
+\frac{\partial F}{\partial v_{2}}=0.
\]

So the cancellation you noticed is not accidental; it is a direct reflection of the fact that ordinary Brownian entropy is a function of the single scale \(D t\).

### Short answer  
No—“ ∂H/∂ln D + ∂H/∂ln t = 0 ” is **not an equilibrium–only fact**.  
It holds whenever the probability density is *self-similar* with Brownian scaling, i.e. it can be written as  

\[
p(\mathbf x,t)=\frac{1}{\bigl(4\pi D t\bigr)^{d/2}}\,
               f\!\Bigl(\frac{\mathbf x}{\sqrt{4Dt}}\Bigr)
\tag{1}
\]

for some *fixed* shape function \(f\) (the heat kernel has \(f(\xi)=e^{-|\xi|^{2}}\)).  
Because (1) depends on \(D\) and \(t\) **only through their product \(Dt\)**, any information–entropy built from it satisfies  

\[
\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln D}
      =-\frac{\partial H}{\partial\ln t}.
\tag{2}
\]

Self-similar solutions are typically far from equilibrium; in fact, an infinite-space Brownian particle has *no* normalisable equilibrium density.

---

## 1 Why the identity appears

Write \(u=\ln D\) and \(v=\ln t\).  For any function of the single combination \(u+v\),

\[
H(u,v)=g(u+v)\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
\partial_u H=g'(u+v)=\partial_v H.
\]

Hence \(\partial_u H+\partial_v H=0\).  Equation (2) is nothing more than this chain-rule fact, with \(H\) as in (1).

---

## 2 When the relation fails

| scenario | entropy expression | do the two derivatives cancel? |
|----------|--------------------|--------------------------------|
| **External potential** (Ornstein–Uhlenbeck, linear drift \(-\gamma x\)) | \(H(t)=\tfrac12\ln\!\bigl(1-e^{-2\gamma t}\bigr)+\text{const.}\) | Depends on \(t\) and \(D/\gamma\) *separately* → (2) fails except at \(t\!\to\!\infty\) (equilibrium) |
| **Time-dependent bath** (\(D=D(t)\)) | Replace \(Dt\) by \(\int_0^{t}D(\tau)d\tau\) | Now \(H\bigl[D(t),t\bigr]\) is not a function of the product alone → (2) fails |
| **Sub/super-diffusion** (\(\langle x^{2}\rangle\propto t^{\alpha}\)) | \(p(\mathbf x,t)\propto t^{-d\!/\!2\alpha}f(|x|/t^{1/2\alpha})\) | Entropy grows like \(\tfrac{d}{2\alpha}\ln t\).  If you still call the prefactor an “effective \(D\)”, the scaling exponent changes and (2) generalises to \(\partial_{\ln D}H=-\alpha\,\partial_{\ln t}H\) but does **not** keep the simple 1:–1 cancellation. |

---

## 3 Equilibrium as a special limit

* With confining drift the system *does* reach a stationary density
  \(p_{\infty}\).  
  Then \(H(t)\to H_{\infty}\) (constant), so both derivatives are **zero** individually; (2) is trivially satisfied.
* For free diffusion there is no stationary measure; the scaling form (1) holds at *all* times, and (2) is non-trivial—even though the process is never in equilibrium.

---

## 4 Take-away rules  

* **Self-similar Brownian scaling** ⇒ \(H\) depends only on \(Dt\).  
  Then \(\partial_{\ln D}H+\partial_{\ln t}H=0\) automatically.  
* The moment a second independent scale enters—drift rate, external potential, variable \(D(t)\), anomalous exponent—**the cancellation breaks down** except possibly in the long-time equilibrium limit.
* So the identity is about **scaling symmetry**, not equilibrium.

parts:
Below I call  

\[
\boxed{\;\mathscr D[F]\;:=\;
\frac{\partial F}{\partial\ln D}\;+\;
\frac{\partial F}{\partial\ln t}}\qquad(\star)
\]

the “\(D\!-\!t\) **divergence**’’ of any quantity \(F(t,D)\).
For the Brownian entropy \(H\) we saw \(\mathscr D[H]=0\) because
\(H\) depends only on the product \(Dt\).
Whenever *that* single-scale symmetry is broken, \(\mathscr D\) picks up
non-zero values that encode interesting physics.

---

## 1 Entropy in the Ornstein–Uhlenbeck (OU) process  

**OU Fokker–Planck**  
\(\partial_t p=\partial_x\bigl[\gamma x\,p+D\,\partial_x p\bigr]\).

Entropy vs time  

\[
H(t,D,\gamma)=\frac12
\Bigl[1+\ln\!\bigl(4\pi D\!\bigl(1-e^{-2\gamma t}\bigr)/\gamma\bigr)\Bigr].
\]

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathscr D[H]=
-\frac{2D\gamma\,e^{-2\gamma t}}
       {D\bigl(1-e^{-2\gamma t}\bigr)}\;=\;-\,2\gamma e^{-2\gamma t}.}
\]

* **Early times**: \(\mathscr D[H]\approx-2\gamma\neq0\) — the confining
  drift destroys Brownian scaling.  
* **Long times**: \(\mathscr D[H]\to0\) as equilibrium is reached.

---

## 2 Entropy for **time-dependent diffusivity** \(D(t)\)

Let \(D(t)=D_{0}(1+\alpha t)\) with \(\alpha>0\).
The exact MSD is
\(\langle x^2\rangle=2\!\int_0^t D(\tau)\,d\tau
                    =2D_{0}(t+\tfrac12\alpha t^{2})\).

Gaussian propagator

\[
p(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4\pi D_{0}(t+\tfrac12\alpha t^{2})}}
       \exp\!\Bigl[-\frac{x^{2}}{4D_{0}(t+\tfrac12\alpha t^{2})}\Bigr].
\]

\[
H(t)=\frac12\Bigl[\,1+\ln\!\bigl(4\pi
                 D_{0}(t+\tfrac12\alpha t^{2})\bigr)\Bigr],
\quad
\boxed{\;
\mathscr D[H]=-\frac{\alpha t}{1+\alpha t/2}\;\neq0\,\,(\forall t>0).}
\]

The non-zero \(\mathscr D\) directly tracks the **rate of diffusivity
growth**.

---

## 3 Generalised (fractional) diffusion, MSD ∝ \(t^{\alpha}\)

Define \(K_\alpha\) by \(\langle x^{2}\rangle=2K_\alpha t^{\alpha}\)
(\(0<\alpha\neq1<2\)).  Write

\[
p(x,t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{4\pi K_\alpha t^{\alpha}}}\,
       f_\alpha\!\Bigl(\frac{x}{\sqrt{4K_\alpha t^{\alpha}}}\Bigr).
\]

Entropy

\[
H(t)=c_\alpha+\frac12\ln t^{\alpha},
\quad
\boxed{\;
\mathscr D[H]=\bigl(1-\alpha\bigr)\,\frac12.}
\]

* Brownian case \(\alpha=1\) ⇒ \(\mathscr D[H]=0\).  
* **Sub-diffusion** \(\alpha<1\): \(\mathscr D[H]>0\).  
* **Super-diffusion** \(\alpha>1\): \(\mathscr D[H]<0\).

Thus \(\mathscr D[H]\) is a **signature of anomalous scaling**.

---

## 4 Non-linear Fokker–Planck / Porous-medium equation  

\[
\partial_t p
  =\partial_{xx}\!\bigl[p^{m}\bigr],\qquad m>1.
\]

Self-similar Barenblatt pulse
\(p(x,t)\propto t^{-1/(m+1)}\bigl(1-\xi^{2}\bigr)_{+}^{1/(m-1)}\)
with
\(\xi=x/t^{1/(m+1)}\).

Entropy (Tsallis form) \(H_{q}(t)\propto\ln t\).
Straightforward differentiation gives

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathscr D[H_q]=
-\frac{1}{m+1}\neq0\;(m>1).}
\]

Non-zero divergence here measures **non-linearity of the transport
mechanism**.

---

## 5 Relative entropy to a **non-stationary reference**  

Take any process with density \(p(x,t)\) and compare to a moving
Gaussian reference \(g(x,t;D_{*})\) with fixed \(D_{*}\):

\[
\mathcal H(t)=\int p\ln\frac{p}{g}\,dx.
\]

One finds

\[
\boxed{
\mathscr D[\mathcal H]
      =\frac{d}{2}\Bigl(\frac{D}{D_{*}}-1\Bigr)
      +D\,\partial_t\!\bigl[\text{KL divergence of centred shapes}\bigr]}.
\]

Unless \(D=D_{*}\) **and** the centred shapes match, \(\mathscr D\) is
non-zero; it quantifies **distance from the chosen reference dynamics**.

---

### Units never clash  
* \(v_1=\ln(1/D)\) and \(v_2=\ln t\) are dimensionless.  
* All \(\mathscr D[F]\) above are dimensionless (information units) or J K\(^{-1}\) if multiplied by \(k_{\!B}\).

---

## Take-away table  

| System / setting | Physics captured by \(\mathscr D[H]\neq0\) |
|------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| OU process | Confining drift, relaxation toward equilibrium |
| \(D=D(t)\) | Non-stationary bath (temperature, viscosity, activity) |
| Fractional diffusion | Sub- or super-diffusive memory effects |
| Porous-medium (non-linear) | Density-dependent mobility |
| Relative entropy to model | Mismatch of actual vs reference diffusivity |

Whenever **Brownian scale invariance is broken**, your divergence
\(\mathscr D\) becomes a compact diagnostic of *what* breaks it and *how
strongly*.

parts:
**Short version — what it is**

“Spectral decomposition” is nothing more mysterious than *writing a linear operator as a weighted sum of its eigen-directions*.  
For a diagonalizable \(n\times n\) matrix \(A\) you pick an eigenbasis \(v_1,\dots ,v_n\):

\[
A v_i \;=\; \lambda_i v_i .
\]

Stack those eigenvectors into a matrix \(V=[\,v_1\;\dots\;v_n]\) and the eigenvalues into a diagonal matrix \(\Lambda=\operatorname{diag}(\lambda_1,\dots ,\lambda_n)\).  
Then

\[
\boxed{\;A \;=\; V\,\Lambda\,V^{-1}\;}
\]

—that boxed formula *is* the finite-dimensional spectral decomposition.  
For a real symmetric or complex Hermitian matrix one can even choose \(V\) to be orthonormal, so \(V^{-1}=V^{\!*}\).

---

### Why people keep talking about it

| Quick payoff | How the decomposition helps |
|--------------|-----------------------------|
| **Solving linear ODEs** \( \dot x = A x \) | \(e^{tA}=V\,e^{t\Lambda}V^{-1}\), so \(x(t)=V e^{t\Lambda}V^{-1}x(0)\). The dynamics split into independent scalar exponentials. |
| **Any matrix function** \(f(A)\) | Compute \(f\) on the diagonal: \(f(A)=V\,f(\Lambda)\,V^{-1}\). Great for \(\sqrt{A}\), \(\log A\), etc. |
| **Power & iteration analysis** | \(A^{k}=V\,\Lambda^{k}\,V^{-1}\). Stability depends on \(|\lambda_i|\). |
| **Quadratic forms / PCA** | A covariance matrix’s spectral decomposition gives principal components; directions with largest \(\lambda_i\) dominate variance. |
| **Normal-mode expansions** | In vibrations, circuits, quantum mechanics, PDEs: eigenvectors are independent modes, eigenvalues are natural frequencies / energies. |

---

### What “spectrum” really means

- **Finite dimension**: the set \(\{\lambda_1,\dots ,\lambda_n\}\).  
- **Infinite dimension**: the spectral theorem says a *normal* operator \(A\) can be written as
  \[
  A \;=\; \int_{\sigma(A)} \lambda\,dE(\lambda),
  \]
  an integral over projection operators \(E(\lambda)\). The finite-dimensional sum above is the special case where the “integral” is just a sum.

---

### When does it fail?

- A matrix that is *not* diagonalizable (think Jordan blocks) lacks a clean spectral decomposition; you need the Jordan form instead.
- Non-normal matrices can still be diagonalizable, but the eigenvectors need not be orthogonal, so numerical work can be unstable.

---

### Relation to things you already know

| Concept | Connection |
|---------|------------|
| **SVD** \(A = U\Sigma V^{\!*}\) | Always exists; diagonalizes \(A\) as a *positive* operator in two different bases. If \(A\) is normal, its SVD and spectral decomposition coincide up to phases. |
| **Fourier transform** | It is the spectral decomposition of the differentiation operator \(d/dx\) on \(L^2(\mathbb{R})\); the “eigenfunctions” are the plane waves \(e^{ikx}\). |
| **Power spectral density** | Decomposes a stationary stochastic process into its frequency components—the spectrum of the auto-covariance operator. |

---

### Bottom line

Spectral decomposition gives you *the coordinate system in which your linear object is already diagonal*. In that system every hard problem (solving, exponentiating, taking square roots, understanding dynamics) collapses to doing the same thing on a bunch of independent scalars \(\lambda_i\). That’s why it keeps showing up everywhere.

parts:
Pretty much — in ordinary \(n\times n\) matrix land, “spectral decomposition” *is* the act of diagonalizing a matrix with its eigenvectors:

\[
A = V\Lambda V^{-1}.
\]

But people keep a separate phrase because the word *spectral* cues two extra layers of generality:

| Term | Narrow, finite-dimensional meaning | Broader operator-theory meaning |
|------|-----------------------------------|---------------------------------|
| **Diagonalization** | Find a basis that turns a matrix into an honest diagonal matrix. Works only when \(A\) is diagonalizable (no Jordan blocks). | Same idea, but fails outright if the operator has nilpotent parts; there’s no diagonal form at all. |
| **Spectral decomposition** | Same formula above, but the emphasis is on the *eigen-structure* (“the spectrum”), not on the coordinate change. | The spectral theorem: every *normal* operator \(A\) on a Hilbert space can be written as an **integral of eigen-projectors**  \(A=\displaystyle\int_{\sigma(A)} \lambda\,dE(\lambda)\).  The “integral” collapses to a sum when the spectrum is discrete (finite matrices). It still works when the spectrum is continuous, where literal diagonalization is impossible. |

So:

* **If \(A\) is diagonalizable** (and you’re staying in finite dimension) the two phrases are interchangeable in practice.
* **If you let the dimension go to infinity**, or allow continuous spectra, “spectral decomposition” continues to make sense while “diagonalization” stops being literal.

That’s why textbooks and practitioners throw the word “spectral” around: it reminds you that behind the friendly diagonal matrix there’s a heavier-duty theorem that survives in PDEs, quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis, etc.

parts:
“Spectral decomposition” is a property of **linear operators**, so a plain scalar-valued function \(f\) does not come with a unique spectrum the way a matrix does.  You have to say *which operator you want to look at*.  There are two standard choices.

---

## 1.  Make \(f\) into an operator (multiplication)

Define  
\[
(M_f g)(x)\;=\;f(x)\,g(x), \qquad g\in L^{2}(\Omega).
\]

- \(M_f\) is **normal** (indeed self-adjoint if \(f\) is real-valued).  
- The spectral theorem applies exactly as for matrices:

\[
M_f \;=\; \int_{\sigma(M_f)} \lambda \, dE(\lambda),
\]

where \(E\) is a projection-valued measure.

**What is the spectrum?**  
\[
\sigma(M_f)=\text{essential range of }f,
\]
i.e.\ all \(\lambda\) for which the set \(\{x : |f(x)-\lambda|<\varepsilon\}\) has positive measure for every \(\varepsilon>0\).

**Why this looks “already diagonal.”**  
In the coordinate system \(x\mapsto\) itself, \(M_f\) acts independently at every point, so the “eigen-projector” for a Borel set \(B\subset\mathbb R\) is simply multiplication by the indicator \(\mathbf 1_{f^{-1}(B)}\).  Nothing to compute—the operator was born diagonal.

---

## 2.  Expand \(f\) in the eigenbasis of *another* operator

Very often people really mean:

> “Write the *vector* \(f\) as a linear combination of eigenfunctions of some differential operator.”

Classical example (Fourier analysis):

| Operator | Eigenfunctions | “Spectral” expansion of \(f\) |
|----------|----------------|-------------------------------|
| \(L=\dfrac{d}{dx}\) on \(L^{2}(\mathbb R)\) | \(e^{ikx}\) with eigenvalue \(ik\) | \(f(x)=\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\!\hat f(k)\,e^{ikx}\,dk\) |
| \(-\dfrac{d^{2}}{dx^{2}}\) on \([0,2\pi]\) with periodic BC | \(\{e^{inx}\}_{n\in\mathbb Z}\), eigenvalue \(n^{2}\) | \(f(x)=\displaystyle\sum_{n\in\mathbb Z}\hat f(n)\,e^{inx}\) |

Here the “spectrum” is the set of eigenvalues of \(L\); the coefficients \(\hat f\) are found by inner products \(\langle e^{inx},f\rangle\).  The same idea underlies spherical-harmonic expansions, wavelets, graph Fourier transforms, etc.

---

### Which viewpoint is “the” spectral decomposition of \(f\)?

- **If you mean \(f\) as an operator**: choice 1, and the answer is trivial—\(M_f\) is already diagonal, spectrum = essential range.
- **If you treat \(f\) as a *vector***: pick an operator \(L\) whose eigenfunctions give a useful basis; expanding \(f\) in that basis is its spectral representation *relative to \(L\)*.

Without specifying the operator, “spectral decomposition of a scalar function” is ambiguous—there is no single canonical one.

thoughts.content: I need to explain how, for a nonlinear operator \(\Phi[f] : H \to H\), its Fréchet derivative \(D\Phi_{f}\) is a linear bounded operator. The operator \(C_{f} = D\Phi_{f}^\ast D\Phi_{f}\) is positive self-adjoint in \(H\), and its spectral decomposition resembles \(J^\top J\) in finite dimensions. parts:
Below is the infinite-dimensional analogue of the “\(J^{\top}J\)” story, laid out step-by-step so you can see exactly where the spectral decomposition enters and what can go wrong.

---

## 1.  Set-up: pick a Hilbert space

Let  
\[
H:=L^{2}(\Omega;\mathbb R^{m})
\]
(or any separable Hilbert space).  
Your nonlinear map is

\[
\Phi:H\longrightarrow H,\qquad f\mapsto f':=\Phi[f].
\]

A concrete example is the **time-\(t\) solution operator** of a dissipative PDE; another is a *flow map* of a nonlinear evolution equation.

---

## 2.  Linearise

At a particular configuration \(f\in H\) the **Fréchet derivative**

\[
D\Phi_{f} : H\;\longrightarrow\;H
\]

is a bounded linear operator that satisfies  
\(\Phi[f+h]=\Phi[f]+D\Phi_{f}h+\mathrm o(\|h\|)\).

(The adjoint \(D\Phi_{f}^{\ast}\) is taken with respect to the \(H\) inner product.)

---

## 3.  Build the positive operator  
\[
\boxed{\;C_{f}:=D\Phi_{f}^{\ast}\,D\Phi_{f}\;}
\]

- \(C_{f}\) is self-adjoint, positive, and -- crucially -- **independent of any particular basis**.  
- In finite dimensions \(C=J^{\top}J\) is exactly the right Cauchy–Green deformation tensor; here \(C_{f}\) plays the same role in the space of fields.

---

## 4.  When the spectral theorem gives eigenfunctions

### A. Compact case (discrete spectrum)

If \(D\Phi_{f}\) is **compact** (e.g. the map is smoothing: Navier–Stokes with \(t>0\), Allen–Cahn, reaction–diffusion, etc.), then

\[
C_{f}u_{k}=\sigma_{k}^{2}u_{k},\qquad
0<\sigma_{1}\ge\sigma_{2}\ge\dots\downarrow0,
\]

with an orthonormal eigenbasis \(\{u_{k}\}\subset H\).  
Define \(v_{k}:=\sigma_{k}^{-1}D\Phi_{f}u_{k}\).  
Then

\[
D\Phi_{f}u_{k}=\sigma_{k}v_{k},\qquad
D\Phi_{f}^{\ast}v_{k}=\sigma_{k}u_{k},
\]

so \(D\Phi_{f}\) has a **singular-value decomposition**

\[
D\Phi_{f}=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\sigma_{k}\,v_{k}\otimes u_{k}^{\ast}.
\]

Everything looks exactly like finite-dimensional SVD; the only change is infinitely many modes.

### B. Non-compact case (continuous spectrum)

Hamiltonian or purely advective dynamics give derivatives that are **not** compact; \(C_{f}\) may have continuous spectrum.  
The spectral theorem still works, but the discrete sum is replaced by an *integral over a projection-valued measure* \(E(\lambda)\):

\[
C_{f}=\int_{\sigma(C_{f})}\lambda\,dE(\lambda).
\]

Eigenfunctions may no longer exist as honest vectors; instead you have generalized “eigen-distributions” (Fourier modes for translation, wave packets for shear, etc.).  
You can still speak of *singular values* \(\sigma=\sqrt{\lambda}\), but now they form a continuum.

---

## 5.  Why \(C_{f}\) is worth decomposing

| Information from \(\sigma_{k},u_{k},v_{k}\) | Interpretation |
|---------------------------------------------|----------------|
| Largest \(\sigma_{k}\)                      | Maximal linear growth of perturbations; leads to **finite-time Lyapunov exponents**. |
| Orthonormal set \(\{u_{k}\}\)               | Principal directions in which the field perturbations stretch or compress; useful for **optimal mixing**, **instability analysis**, **shape sensitivity**. |
| Energy truncation \(\sum_{k=1}^{r}\sigma_{k}^{2}\) | Natural basis for **proper orthogonal decomposition (POD)** or reduced-order models. |
| Kernel representation \(C_{f}(x,y)\)        | Gives **two-point correlation** of linearised responses; Mercer's theorem applies when \(C_{f}\) is Hilbert–Schmidt. |

In dissipative PDEs these eigenpairs converge as \(t\to\infty\) to the **covariant Lyapunov vectors**; in stochastic settings \(C_{f}\) connects to the **Fisher information metric** and **stochastic Cauchy–Green tensors**.

---

## 6.  Practical computation routes

1. **Galerkin projection** – expand \(D\Phi_{f}\) in a finite element / Fourier basis, form the matrix, do an ordinary SVD.  
2. **Nyström method** – approximate the kernel \(C_{f}(x,y)\) from samples and solve a matrix eigenproblem.  
3. **Adjoint–based power iteration** – repeatedly apply \(D\Phi_{f}\) and its adjoint to converge on leading singular functions when only matrix-free actions are available.

---

## 7.  Summary mantra

> *Take the Fréchet derivative, square it with its adjoint, and diagonalise the result.*  
> If the derivative is compact you get a discrete SVD; if not you get a continuous spectral measure. Either way, the spectrum tells you exactly how infinitesimal perturbations of your field are stretched, rotated, or suppressed by the nonlinear map.

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the spectrum of singular values for certain operators, particularly if they are countably infinite or continuous. For compact operators in infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces, their spectrum is countably infinite and discrete, accumulating only at zero. However, non-compact operators (e.g., unbounded or involving advection) can have a continuous spectrum. The key distinction is between compact operators (which have discrete spectra) and general bounded operators (which can have continuous spectra).

The spectral theorem says that if an operator is compact and self-adjoint, its spectrum is discrete, with singular values accumulating only at zero. For non-compact, bounded self-adjoint operators, the spectrum can be continuous. For example, multiplication by a function with a continuous range leads to a continuous spectrum. The key distinction is that compactness provides discrete singular values, while non-compact operators often have continuous spectra. Operators with smoothing effects, like diffusion, lead to compactness, while advective or Hamiltonian flows don’t.

parts:
### Short answer  
- **If the linearised map \(D\Phi_f\) is *compact*** (smoothing, dissipative, etc.) then
  - the positive operator \(C_f=D\Phi_f^{\!*}D\Phi_f\) has **only a countable set** of non-zero eigenvalues  
    \(\sigma_1^2\ge\sigma_2^2\ge\ldots\downarrow0\);
  - those \(\sigma_k\) are your singular values.  
- **If \(D\Phi_f\) is *not* compact** (pure transport, rigid shift, Hamiltonian flow, …) the spectrum can include a **continuous part**; then talking about “the list \(\{\sigma_k\}\)” stops making sense and you need a spectral density instead.

---

## Why compact ⇒ countable (Riesz–Schauder idea in one line)

For a **compact** operator every bounded sequence \(h_n\) has a convergent subsequence \(C_f h_{n_j}\).  
That forces the resolvent \((C_f-\lambda I)^{-1}\) to be *Fredholm*, and the only way an eigenvalue \(\lambda\neq0\) can accumulate is at \(\lambda=0\).  
Hence the non-zero spectrum is **discrete with finite multiplicity**, so at most countably many \(\sigma_k\).

---

## Intuition: smoothing vs. rearranging  

| Operator type | What it does to perturbations | Spectrum of \(C_f\) |
|---------------|------------------------------|---------------------|
| **Heat map** \(f\mapsto e^{t\Delta}f\) | kills high-frequencies exponentially | \(\sigma_k=e^{-t|k|^2}\) — countable, ↓ to 0 |
| **Shift** \(f(x)\mapsto f(x+s)\) | just re-labels points, no decay | \(C_f=I\) ⇒ spectrum = \(\{1\}\) continuous (multiplicity \(=\infty\)) |
| **Advection** \(f_t+u\cdot\nabla f=0\) | redistributes, keeps all scales | continuous spectrum on \([0,1]\) (depends on \(u\)) |

Compactness is a *property of the map*, **not** of “vector vs. field”.  
Many infinite-dimensional maps (heat, reaction–diffusion, Navier–Stokes at positive time) are compact; many others (pure transport, Schrödinger group, rigid translations) are not.

---

## What to do when the spectrum is continuous  

You replace the discrete SVD  

\[
D\Phi_f\,h=\sum_k\sigma_k\,\langle u_k,h\rangle\,v_k
\]

by a *spectral integral*  

\[
D\Phi_f\,h=\int_{\sigma(C_f)}\sqrt{\lambda}\;dE_\lambda\,h,
\]

where \(E_\lambda\) is the projection-valued measure from the spectral theorem.  
Eigenfunctions become “generalised” (plane waves, wave packets, etc.); the notion of *singular value* turns into a density \(\sqrt{\lambda}\).

---

### Take-away  

- **Countably infinite \(\sigma_k\)** is *typical* whenever the linearised operator is compact (any smoothing influence).  
- You get a **continuous band** only when the dynamics preserve all scales and the derivative fails to be compact.  

So the jump from a finite-dimensional vector to an infinite-dimensional field *doesn’t by itself* force a continuous spectrum; it all hinges on how your map treats high-frequency perturbations.

thoughts.content: To explain why compactness implies a discrete spectrum and finite-dimensional-like behavior, we can focus on the intuition behind compact operators. A compact operator maps the unit ball of a space to a relatively compact set, meaning that its image can be approximated by finite-dimensional subspaces. As a result, the infinite-dimensional directions get "compressed," and higher modes are dampened. This leads to eigenvalues accumulating at zero, creating a discrete spectrum—similar to what we observe in finite-dimensional spaces. It's about how the operator effectively reduces dimensionality.

Compact operators "shrink" dimensionality because their images of the unit ball are relatively compact and can be approximated by finite-dimensional subspaces. This happens because compact—especially self-adjoint—operators have eigenvalues decaying to zero with finite multiplicity. High-frequency modes are progressively dampened. Intuitively, operators like heat flow reduce the contribution of high modes. Singular values decay quickly, and by a given threshold, only small ones survive, mimicking finite-dimensional behavior. A compact operator can be approximated closely by a finite-rank operator within any ε, making high modes almost negligible.

parts:
### 1 What “compact” really says  
Take the closed unit ball \(B=\{h\in H:\|h\|\le 1\}\) of your (infinite-dimensional) Hilbert space \(H\).

*For a **compact** operator \(T\)* the image \(T(B)\) is **totally bounded**:  
for every \(\varepsilon>0\) you can cover \(T(B)\) with finitely many radius-\(\varepsilon\) balls.

---

### 2 Why that already looks “finite-dimensional”  

If only finitely many \(\varepsilon\)-balls are needed, there must be a finite-dimensional subspace \(E_\varepsilon\subset H\) whose orthogonal projector \(P_\varepsilon\) captures *almost* the entire image:

\[
\|T - P_\varepsilon T\|\;<\;\varepsilon .
\]

> **Key intuition** – *Compactness ⇔ “up to any fixed accuracy, the operator behaves as if it had finite rank.”*  
> The higher-codimension directions cannot carry sizeable vectors; they are flattened until they fit into the small leftover \(\varepsilon\)-ball.

---

### 3 Spectral consequences for \(C=T^{\!*}T\)

For a compact, self-adjoint, positive operator \(C\):

1. **Eigenvectors exist** and form an orthonormal basis of \(H\).  
2. Non-zero eigenvalues can only accumulate at \(0\).  
3. Each eigenspace is finite-dimensional.

Hence the list of singular values \(\sigma_k=\sqrt{\lambda_k}\) is

\[
\sigma_1\;\ge\;\sigma_2\;\ge\;\dots\;\downarrow\;0,
\]
a **countable** sequence with \(\sigma_k\to0\).

Above any threshold \(\varepsilon\) there are only finitely many singular values.

---

### 4 Geometric picture  

| Finite dimension | Infinite but **compact** | Infinite non-compact |
|------------------|--------------------------|----------------------|
| Unit ball goes to an ellipsoid with \(n\) axes | Unit ball goes to an ellipsoid with **countably many** axes whose lengths \(\sigma_k\) shrink to \(0\). Past some index \(k_*\) the axes fit inside any pre-set small radius. | Unit ball is merely stretched/rotated; the image still has full “thickness’’ in infinitely many directions, so no finite \(\varepsilon\)-cover is possible. |

---

### 5 Concrete example: heat vs. shift  

*Heat operator* \(e^{t\Delta}\) in Fourier basis  
\[
\widehat{T f}(k)=e^{-t|k|^{2}}\hat f(k)\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\sigma_k=e^{-t|k|^{2}}\xrightarrow{|k|\to\infty}0.
\]

*Shift* \(Sf(x)=f(x+s)\) has \(|\widehat{S}|=1\) for every mode → spectrum \(=\{1\}\) with infinite multiplicity (continuous block); \(S\) is unitary, not compact.

---

### 6 Take-away sentence  

> **Compactness doesn’t literally “cut the dimension down”; it just forces every high-codimension direction to be squashed so strongly that, beyond a countable set of principal axes, the operator acts as if it were zero.**  
> That collapse of large-index singular values to \(0\) is exactly what turns the spectrum from a continuum into a discrete, countable ladder.
